Quiz Results

Quiz Attempt #119727

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in different cities A-E along with the ratio of number of people in three different age groups I, II and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.City-wise Number of peopleCityNumber of people (in lakhs)Ratio of Number of people in Age-groupsI : II : IIIA14.41 : 3 : 2B162 : 3 : 3C19.21: 1 : 2D12.83 : 1 : 4E121 : 3 : 1For city C, if the number of people who will turn 21 years of age next year is 16000; the number of new born will be 32000, and the number of people in age group III will remain the same, then what will be the ratio of people in different age groups?
  • A.31 : 31 : 60
  • B.31 : 32 : 60
  • C.31 : 32 : 56
  • D.21 : 23 : 35
Correct Answer: 31 : 31 : 60

Number of people in Group I = 14 × 19.2 = 480000

Number of people in Group II = 14 × 19.2 = 480000

Number of people in Group III: 24 × 19.2 = 960000

People turning 21 next year (moving from Group I to Group II): 16000

Newborns (adding to Group I): 32000

  • Number of people in Group III remains the same: 960000

New Ratio = 496000 : 496000 : 960000 = 31 : 31 : 60

Question 2
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in different cities A-E along with the ratio of number of people in three different age groups I, II and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.City-wise Number of peopleCityNumber of people (in lakhs)Ratio of Number of people in Age-groupsI : II : IIIA14.41 : 3 : 2B162 : 3 : 3C19.21: 1 : 2D12.83 : 1 : 4E121 : 3 : 1What is the ratio of the number of people of age group-I of city A and D together to the number of people of age group-I of city C and E together?
  • A.1 : 2
  • B.1: 1
  • C.2: 1
  • D.3: 2
Correct Answer: 1: 1

Required ratio = 16×14.4+38×12.814×19.2+15×12 = 1:1

Question 3
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in different cities A-E along with the ratio of number of people in three different age groups I, II and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.City-wise Number of peopleCityNumber of people (in lakhs)Ratio of Number of people in Age-groupsI : II : IIIA14.41 : 3 : 2B162 : 3 : 3C19.21: 1 : 2D12.83 : 1 : 4E121 : 3 : 1The difference between the total number of people in age group II of city A and B together and age group III of city C and E together is
  • A.2 lakhs
  • B.1.2 lakhs
  • C.2.4 lakhs
  • D.0.8 lakhs
Correct Answer: 1.2 lakhs
  • Required difference = 36×14.4+38×16 - 24×19.2+15×12

= 1.2 lakhs

Question 4
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in different cities A-E along with the ratio of number of people in three different age groups I, II and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.City-wise Number of peopleCityNumber of people (in lakhs)Ratio of Number of people in Age-groupsI : II : IIIA14.41 : 3 : 2B162 : 3 : 3C19.21: 1 : 2D12.83 : 1 : 4E121 : 3 : 1Number of people of age group I is more than 4 lakhs in exactly _________ city/cities.
  • A.one
  • B.two
  • C.three
  • D.four
Correct Answer: two
  • City-wise Number of people
  •  
  • City
  • Number of people (in lakhs)
  • Ratio of Number of people in Age-groups
  • I : II : III
  • Number of People in Group 1
  • A
  • 14.4
  • 1 : 3 : 2
  • 16×14.4=2.4
  • B
  • 16
  • 2 : 3 : 3
  • 28×16=2
  • C
  • 19.2
  • 1: 1 : 2
  • 14×19.2=4.8
  • D
  • 12.8
  • 3 : 1 : 4
  • 38×12.8=4.8
  • E
  • 12
  • 1 : 3 : 1
  • 15×12=2.4

Number of people of age Group I is more than 4 lakhs in exactly two city/cities.

Question 5
The following table shows the number of people (in lakhs) living in different cities A-E along with the ratio of number of people in three different age groups I, II and III among them. People are classified in three age groups as Group-I: 0 to less than 21 years; Group-II: 21 to less than 41 years and Group-III: 41 years and above. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.City-wise Number of peopleCityNumber of people (in lakhs)Ratio of Number of people in Age-groupsI : II : IIIA14.41 : 3 : 2B162 : 3 : 3C19.21: 1 : 2D12.83 : 1 : 4E121 : 3 : 1Number of people in age group III of city D is ------- % more than that of age group II of city B.
  • A.7%
  • B.614%
  • C.623%
  • D.6%
Correct Answer: 623%
  • Required percentage = 48×12.8-38×1638×16 × 100

= 623 %

Question 6
In computer Networking, MAC addresses are unique to each device. Which of the following is the meaning of the term MAC?
  • A.Medium Access Card
  • B.Media Address Command
  • C.Modem Addressing card
  • D.Media Access Control
Correct Answer: Media Access Control
  • Option D is the correct answer.
  •  

MAC (Media Access Control) addresses are unique identifiers assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network layer. It’s a hardware address embedded into devices like network interface cards (NICs) by the manufacturer.

  •  

A MAC address is essential for network communication as it helps devices on the same network identify each other. For example, when data is transmitted over a local network, the MAC address ensures the data reaches the correct device.

Question 7
A Symbol that represents an idea or thought in non-verbal communication is referred to as:
  • A.Hidden Symbol
  • B.Effective Symbol
  • C.Abstract Symbol
  • D.Ideational Symbol
Correct Answer: Abstract Symbol

An abstract symbol is a representation that does not visually resemble the object or concept it represents. These symbols often take the form of geometric shapes or designs and are used to convey complex ideas or brand identities in a conceptual manner, rather than through recognizable imagery. For example, the Infinity Symbol (∞) conveys the concept of infinity or endlessness abstractly, without resorting to a visual representation.

Question 8
Which of thefollowinginstitutions were to play a role in shaping the National System of Education at higher level under the National Education Policy (1986)?A. UNESCOB. UNDPC. UGCD. AICTEE. ICARChoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

The correct answer is (D) C, D and E only.

  •  

The National Education Policy (NEP) of 1986 aimed to improve and regulate higher education in India. The following institutions were involved in shaping the national system of higher education:

  •  

UGC (University Grants Commission): Responsible for coordinating, determining, and maintaining standards of higher education in India.

  •  

AICTE (All India Council for Technical Education): Oversees technical education in India, including engineering, technology, and management programs.

  •  

ICAR (Indian Council of Agricultural Research): Plays a role in the improvement and development of agricultural education and research.

  •  

UNESCO (A) and UNDP (B) are international organizations that assist in educational development globally but do not directly shape India's higher education policy as outlined in NEP 1986.

Question 9
Identify correct statements about content analysis.A.The main useofcontent analysis has been in the examination of printed texts and documents.B.Content analysis lacks transparency.C.Coding is crucial in content analysis.D.It is almost impossible to devise coding manuals that do not entail some interpretation the part of coders.Choose the correctanswer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.A, B and D only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only
  • The correct answer is option (C) - A, C and D only.
  •  
  • (A) The main use of content analysis has been in the examination of printed texts and documents.
  • This statement is correct. Content analysis is indeed primarily used to analyze various forms of textual data, including printed texts, documents, and more recently, digital content such as websites and social media.
  •  
  • (B) Content analysis lacks transparency.
  • This statement is incorrect. Content analysis is generally considered a systematic and transparent research method. While there may be some subjective elements, especially in the coding process, the method itself aims for transparency by following structured procedures.
  •  
  • (C) Coding is crucial in content analysis.
  • This statement is correct. Coding is a fundamental part of content analysis, where researchers categorize and quantify content to facilitate analysis.
  •  
  • (D) It is almost impossible to devise coding manuals that do not entail some interpretation on the part of coders.

This statement is also correct. Since coding involves interpreting the content, it is challenging to create entirely objective coding manuals without any interpretative input from the coders.

Question 10
Biomass:A. isa carbon neutral fuel.B. has significantly higher calorific value then coal.C. can be converted in solid, liquid and gaseous fuels.D. can be converted into Producer Gas.E. cannot be obtained from energy crops.Choose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A, C and D only
  • C.B, D and E only
  • D.A, B and E only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only
  • The correct answer is (B) A, C and D only.
  •  
  • A. Biomass is a carbon-neutral fuel:
  • True. Biomass is considered carbon-neutral because the carbon dioxide (CO₂) it releases during combustion is roughly equal to the amount absorbed by plants during their growth, making it a renewable energy source.
  •  
  • B. Biomass has a significantly higher calorific value than coal:
  • False. Biomass generally has a lower calorific value than coal. Coal, being a fossil fuel, is more energy-dense and releases more energy per unit of weight when burned.
  •  
  • C. Biomass can be converted into solid, liquid, and gaseous fuels:
  • True. Biomass can be transformed into different types of fuels:
  • Solid fuels: like wood pellets.
  • Liquid fuels: such as bioethanol or biodiesel.
  • Gaseous fuels: like biogas.
  •  
  • D. Biomass can be converted into Producer Gas:
  • True. Biomass can be converted into producer gas, a mixture of carbon monoxide, hydrogen, and nitrogen, through a process called gasification.
  •  
  • E. Biomass cannot be obtained from energy crops:

False. Biomass can be obtained from energy crops like switchgrass, sugarcane, and corn, which are grown specifically for energy production.

Question 11
Based on the following, which of the following statements are true?A ‘CD’ contains 12 music tracks which are of lengths (in minute):3, 7, 4, 3, 5, 6, 4, 5, 4, 7, 8, 8And each minute of music requires 12 MB of storage.
  • A.512 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • B.1 GB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • C.768 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • D.If the tracks are to be stored in MP3 format, then each music track will be reduced in size by 90%. The storage that the 12 tracks would require is 69.12 MB.
Correct Answer: 768 MB of memory is used for the 12 music tracks.
  • Let's calculate the total memory required for the 12 music tracks and evaluate the statements.
  •  
  • Track lengths (in minutes):
  • 3, 7, 4, 3, 5, 6, 4, 5, 4, 7, 8, 8
  •  
  • Total length of music:
  • Sum of track lengths = 3 + 7 + 4 + 3 + 5 + 6 + 4 + 5 + 4 + 7 + 8 + 8 = 64 minutes
  •  
  • Memory required per minute:
  • Each minute of music requires 12 MB of storage.
  •  
  • Total memory required (in MB):
  •  

Total memory = 64 minutes × 12 MB = 768 MB

Question 12
Most recommendations of the Calcutta University Commission were influenced by:
  • A.The Hunter commission
  • B.Wood’s Dispatch
  • C.The Haldane Commission
  • D.The Indian Universities Commission
Correct Answer: The Haldane Commission
  • Option C is the correct answer.
  •  
  • The Sadler Commission, also known as the Calcutta University Commission, was established by the British government in 1917 to investigate and make recommendations on the problems and future development of the University of Calcutta. The commission was named after its chairman, Sir Michael Sadler.
  •  

The Haldane Commission submitted its report in 1913 and presented its report for University of London. However, its recommendations were taken into consideration only after First World War.

Question 13
In a certain coding scheme the word ‘SCHOLAR’ is coded as ‘TEKSQGY’. In the same coding scheme, the word ‘GREEN’ will be coded as:
  • A.ITGGP
  • B.HTHIS
  • C.EPCGP
  • D.JUHHQ
Correct Answer: HTHIS
  • S

Question 14
Which of the followingtool is used to create pre and post-session polls to gauge students learning from each session?
  • A.Mentimeter
  • B.Github
  • C.Plotagon
  • D.Labster
Correct Answer: Mentimeter

The correct answer is option (A) - Mentimeter.

Mentimeter is an interactive tool that allows educators and presenters to create live polls, quizzes, word clouds, and Q&A sessions. It is widely used for pre- and post-session polls to assess student understanding before and after a session. It helps gauge learning progress, gather feedback, and engage participants interactively during classes or presentations.

Question 15
With reference to ICT, which of thefollowingstatement is true?
  • A.Global Positioning Systems (GPS) in cars send signals to satellite which then work out where they are and send this data back to the car.
  • B.HTTP stands for Hyper-Text Transfer Policy.
  • C.RAM stands for Rapid Access Memory.
  • D.Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer based tool for mapping and analysing things that exist and events that happen on earth.
Correct Answer: Geographic Information System (GIS) is a computer based tool for mapping and analysing things that exist and events that happen on earth.
  • Option D is the correct answer.
  •  
  • Geographic Information System (GIS) is a tool that helps in the mapping and analysis of geographic data. It is used in various fields like urban planning, environmental monitoring, and disaster management to visualize spatial data and analyze real-world events.
  •  
  • RAM stands for Random Access Memory, which is a type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly and is used for storing data that is actively being used by the system.
  •  
  • HTTP stands for HyperText Transfer Protocol, not "Policy". It is the protocol used for transmitting web pages over the internet.

 

GPS works by receiving signals from satellites, not by sending them. The GPS device in a car receives signals from at least 3 satellites and calculates its location based on the time it takes for the signals to arrive.

Question 16
Making way for technologies of automation is ________ transformation of modern society.
  • A.Cyber-nation
  • B.Mechanical
  • C.Political
  • D.Artificial
Correct Answer: Cyber-nation
  • Option A is the correct answer.
  •  

Cyber-nation refers to the use of computers, automation, and information technology to replace human labour in various processes and industries. This term is often associated with the transformation of society where machines, robots, and computers take over tasks that were previously performed by humans. This is part of the broader trend of automation in modern society.

Question 17
Thestyle that involves a student’s tendency to make more time to respond on the accuracy of answers is known as:
  • A.Impulsive style
  • B.Surface style
  • C.Reflective style
  • D.Manipulative style
Correct Answer: Reflective style
  • Option C is the correct answer.
  •  

Reflective style is characterized by a tendency to take time to think through answers and focus on the accuracy and depth of responses. Students who adopt a reflective style carefully consider their knowledge, analyze problems, and evaluate their answers before responding, leading to more thoughtful and accurate contributions.

Question 18
“Abhay’smind is a cave, deep, dark and full of bats”. Which of the following is correct about the above statement?
  • A.It contains analogical argument
  • B.It is a valid and sound argument
  • C.It contains analogy
  • D.It is a valid but not a sound argument
Correct Answer: It contains analogy
  • The correct answer is option (C) - It contains analogy.
  •  
  • The statement “Abhay’s mind is a cave, deep, dark and full of bats” is a metaphorical expression rather than a logical argument.
  •  

(C) It contains analogy: This option is correct because the phrase draws a comparison between Abhay's mind and a cave, suggesting complexity and darkness. This comparison highlights specific qualities (depth and darkness) metaphorically associated with his mind, thus qualifying as an analogy.

Question 19
In the early stages of development, broadcast media were marked by
  • A.Positive Communication
  • B.Negative communication
  • C.One-way communication
  • D.Two-way communication
Correct Answer: One-way communication

The correct answer is option (C) - One-way communication.

  •  

In the early stages of broadcast media, communication was primarily one-way, meaning that information was transmitted from the broadcaster (such as radio or television stations) to the audience without any feedback or interaction from the audience. Viewers or listeners received the content passively, with no opportunity to respond or engage in dialogue.

Question 20
Match theList-IwithList-II.List I (ICT Tools)A.Learning Management System (LMS)B. Virtual RealityC. Video ConferencingD. PodcastList II (Example)I. ZoomII. CanvasIII. AudacityIV.VirbelaChoose the Correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • B.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • The correct answer is option (C) - A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III.
  •  
  • A. Learning Management System (LMS) - II. Canvas
  • Canvas is a popular Learning Management System used in educational settings to create, manage, and deliver online courses.
  •  
  • B. Virtual Reality - IV. Virbela
  • Virbela is a virtual reality platform that provides immersive environments for meetings, events, and education, making it suitable for virtual reality experiences.
  •  
  • C. Video Conferencing - I. Zoom
  • Zoom is a widely-used video conferencing tool that allows users to hold virtual meetings, webinars, and online classes, making it the correct match for video conferencing.
  •  
  • D. Podcast - III. Audacity

Audacity is an audio editing software that is often used for creating and editing podcasts. It allows users to record and edit audio files, making it a suitable tool for podcast production.

Question 21
Which of the followingis an example of positive-transfer of learning?
  • A.Mastering algebra helps in understanding Calculus.
  • B.Learning to play piano makes it more difficult to learn the violin.
  • C.Knowing how to drive a car makes it harder to learn how to ride a bicycle.
  • D.Learning to speak French hinders learning Spanish.
Correct Answer: Mastering algebra helps in understanding Calculus.

The correct answer is option (A) - Mastering algebra helps in understanding Calculus.

  •  

Positive transfer of learning occurs when previous knowledge or skills facilitate the acquisition of new knowledge or skills. In this case, if mastering algebra helps in understanding Calculus, it means that the skills and concepts learned in algebra positively contribute to learning Calculus.

Question 22
International Solar Alliance (ISA) is the alliance of countries, most of which lie:
  • A.Between North Pole and Tropic of Cancer
  • B.Between Tropic of Capricorn and South Pole
  • C.At Equator
  • D.Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn
Correct Answer: Between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn

The International Solar Alliance is an action-oriented, member-driven, intergovernmental organisation for increased deployment of solar energy technologies as a means for bringing energy access, ensuring energy security, and driving energy transition in its Member Countries.

Question 23
Thecriterion of ‘credibility’ in qualitative research is which of the following criteria in quantitative research?
  • A.external validity
  • B.internal validity
  • C.objectivity
  • D.reliability
Correct Answer: internal validity

Credibility, which refers to confidence in the truth value of the findings, has been viewed as the qualitative equivalent of internal validity.

Question 24
Which of the followingstatements are logically equivalent?A. Some beverages are not liquids.B. Some beverages are liquids.C.Some non-liquids are not non-beverages.D.Some beverages are non-liquids.Choose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

The statements A, C and D are logically equivalent.

Question 25
In any conventional media, the point of content production and the point of consumption involve:
  • A.Temporal separation
  • B.Imaginary hurdles
  • C.Free marketing
  • D.Technological over-dependence
Correct Answer: Temporal separation

The correct answer is option - (A) Temporal separation.

  •  

In conventional media, such as newspapers, radio, and television, there is usually a temporal separation between content production and content consumption. Content is created, edited, and published or broadcast at one point in time, and it is consumed by the audience at a later time. This delay is characteristic of traditional media formats, as opposed to real-time media, where content can be created and consumed simultaneously (e.g., live streaming).

Question 26
Due to Over fertilization of lakes, quality of fish produced:
  • A.doesnot change.
  • B.impaires.
  • C.improves.
  • D.firstimproves thenimpaires.
Correct Answer: impaires.

The correct answer is option (B) - impaires.

  •  

Over-fertilization of lakes, often due to excessive nutrient input (particularly nitrogen and phosphorus from agricultural runoff), leads to eutrophication. This process increases algae growth, which can result in harmful algal blooms. When algae die, they decompose, consuming oxygen in the water and creating low-oxygen (hypoxic) conditions. These conditions are harmful to fish and other aquatic organisms, affecting their health, survival rates, and the quality of fish produced. Therefore, over-fertilization impairs the quality of fish in affected lakes.

Question 27
Hydrochlorofluorocarbons(HCFCs), replacement for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), have to be phased out completely by the year:
  • A.2025
  • B.2030
  • C.2035
  • D.2040
Correct Answer: 2030

Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) are gases used worldwide in refrigeration, air-conditioning and foam applications, but they are being phased out under the Montreal Protocol since deplete the ozone layer. HCFCs are both ODS and powerful greenhouse gases: the most commonly used HCFC is nearly 2,000 times more potent than carbon dioxide in terms of its global warming potential (GWP). Recognizing the potential benefits to the Earth’s climate, in September 2007 the Parties decided to accelerate their schedule to phase out HCFCs. Developed countries have been reducing their consumption of HCFCs and will completely phase them out by 2020. Developing countries agreed to start their phase-out process in 2013 and are now following a stepwise reduction until the complete phase-out of HCFCs by 2030.

Question 28
“I have read that one aspirin takeneverydayreduces the risk of heart attack. Why not take two a day double the protection.” Which informal fallacy is committed in the above statement?
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Begging the question
  • C.Hasty generalisation
  • D.Slippery slope
Correct Answer: Fallacy of composition
  • The correct answer is fallacy of composition.
  •  

The fallacy of composition is a logical fallacy that occurs when the argument assumes that if something is true of one thing, it must be true of all things.

Question 29
A quantitative research would be mainly concerned withA. measurementB. causalityC. contextD. replicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A, B and D only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only
  • The correct answer is option (B) - A, B and D only.
  •  
  • Quantitative research primarily focuses on:
  • Measurement (A): Quantitative research is concerned with measuring variables using numerical data to analyze patterns, relationships, or frequencies.
  •  
  • Causality (B): It often seeks to establish causal relationships between variables, explaining how changes in one variable affect another.
  •  
  • Replication (D): Quantitative studies emphasize replicability, allowing other researchers to reproduce the study and verify results.
  •  

Context (C) is more relevant to qualitative research, which seeks to understand phenomena in their natural settings and considers the influence of contextual factors.

Question 30
Sharpness of the peak of a statistical distribution is represented by:
  • A.Kurtosis
  • B.Skewness
  • C.Mean
  • D.Median
Correct Answer: Kurtosis

The correct answer is option (A) – Kurtosis.

 

Kurtosis measures the sharpness, or "peakedness," of a statistical distribution's peak. It indicates whether data are heavy-tailed or light-tailed relative to a normal distribution. Higher kurtosis means a sharper peak and more outliers, while lower kurtosis suggests a flatter distribution.

Question 31
Thenumerator and denominator degrees of freedom are used in which of the following test-statistic in hypothesis testing?
  • A.t
  • B.F
  • C.Z
  • D.χ2(chi square)
Correct Answer: F

The correct answer is option (B) - F.

The F-test in hypothesis testing relies on both numerator and denominator degrees of freedom to calculate the F-ratio, which is used to compare the variances of two or more groups. This test is commonly applied in ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) and other settings where multiple sample variances are analyzed.

Question 32
Three positive numbers are in the ratio2 :3 : 4. If the sum of their squares is 2349, then the numbers respectively are:
  • A.14, 21 and 28
  • B.18, 27 and 36
  • C.16, 24 and 32
  • D.12, 18 and 24
Correct Answer: 18, 27 and 36
  • Let the numbers be 2x, 3x and 4x.
  • Then, (2x)2 + (3x)2 + (4x)2 = 2349
  • or 4x2 + 9x2 + 16x2 = 2349
  • or 29x2 = 2349
  • or x2 = 234929 = 81
  • or x = 9

So, the numbers are 18, 27 and 36.

Question 33
Arrange the followingterms in order of decreasing in intension?A. Baseball playerB. AthleteC. FielderD. Ball playerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, D, A, B
  • B.B, A, D, C
  • C.C, A, D, B
  • D.B, D, A, C
Correct Answer: C, A, D, B
  • The "intension" of a term refers to the inherent qualities or attributes that define it, so a term with greater intension has more specific attributes than a broader, more general term. Arranging the terms from most specific to most general:
  •  
  • C. Fielder – Most specific; a fielder is a specific type of baseball player with a specialized role.
  • A. Baseball player – Broader than "fielder"; encompasses all positions in baseball, not just fielders.
  • D. Ball player – Slightly broader; includes anyone who plays a game with a ball.

B. Athlete – Broadest term; applies to anyone involved in physical sports or activities, including but not limited to baseball.

Question 34
Theeducation imparted atNalandaUniversity was both religious and:
  • A.Irreligious
  • B.Entertaining
  • C.Secular
  • D.Business- Oriented
Correct Answer: Secular

Established around the 5th century CE, Nalanda University provided education on a variety of subjects that went beyond religious teachings. Students at Nalanda studied a broad range of disciplines, including philosophy, medicine, mathematics, astronomy, and logic, reflecting a secular or non-religious approach to education alongside Buddhist teachings.

Question 35
In what time will a sum of money double itself at the rate of 12.5 % per annum simple interest?
  • A.10 years
  • B.8 years
  • C.6 years
  • D.12 years
Correct Answer: 8 years
  • Let P be the principle and T be the time.
  • Then, P = P×12.5×T100

Or T = 10012.5 = 8 years

Question 36
According to classical Indian school of logic (Nyaya) the statement “fire is cold because it is a substance” is fallacious because:
  • A.It has a non-inferentially contradicted middle term.
  • B.The middle term has an impossible locus.
  • C.the middle term instead of proving its presence in major term proves its absence
  • D.The major term proves its presence
Correct Answer: It has a non-inferentially contradicted middle term.
  • Given statement is a type of ‘badhita’ fallacy.
  •  

Badhita is the non-inferentially contradicted middle. Here the middle term is contradicted by some other pramana and not by inference. It cannot prove the major term which is disproved by another stronger source of valid knowledge; e.g., ‘fire is cold, because it is a substance'. Here the middle term ‘substance' becomes contradicted because its major term ‘coldness' is directly contradicted by perception.

Question 37
Which of the following“Digital India” themes is incorrectly matched with its purpose?
  • A.Spoken Tutorial - Learn various free and open-source software all by oneself
  • B.FOSSEE - Reduce dependency on proprietary software in Educational Institutions
  • C.e-Kalpa- Create Digital-learning environment for design
  • D.e-Shodhsindhu- spread education in Embedded systems and robotics
Correct Answer: e-Shodhsindhu- spread education in Embedded systems and robotics
  • Only option D is incorrectly match. Rest are correct.
  •  

In response to the recommendations of an Expert Committee, the Ministry of Human Resource Development (now known as the Ministry of Education) has established e-ShodhSindhu by merging three consortia initiatives: UGC-INFONET Digital Library Consortium, NLIST, and INDEST-AICTE Consortium. e-ShodhSindhu is designed to provide both current and archival access to over 10,000 core and peer-reviewed journals, along with a variety of bibliographic, citation, and factual databases across multiple disciplines. This extensive resource is available to member institutions, including centrally funded technical institutions, universities, and colleges recognized under Sections 12(B) and 2(f) of the UGC Act.

Question 38
“If a student gets a part time job in an architect’s office and applies what was learnt in geometry class to help the architectanalyzea spatial problem that is quite different from any problem the student encountered in geometry class” is an example of ________ learning?
  • A.Near transfer
  • B.Forward- reaching transfer
  • C.Low-road transfer
  • D.Far transfer
Correct Answer: Far transfer
  • Option D is the correct answer.
  •  

Transfer refers to learning in one context and applying it to another, i.e. the capacity to apply acquired knowledge and skills to new situations.

  •  

Near transfer - This occurs when a person applies a learned skill to a context almost identical to that in which the skill was learned. For example, an employee learning how to use a new type of software in the business can then transfer that learning directly to the workplace.

  •  

Far transfer - This occurs when the learning context and the new context are dissimilar. Far transfer is more challenging in that it involves applying principles and using judgement not required with near transfer. An example of far transfer would be applying problem-solving skills learned in a math class to make financial decisions in real life.

Question 39
If a person travels in a car at a speed of 36 km/hour, then he will reach his destination on time. He covers half the journey in (4/5)thtime.What should be his speed for remaining part of the journey so that he reaches his destination on time?
  • A.80 km/hour
  • B.75 km/hour
  • C.90 km/hour
  • D.85 km/hour
Correct Answer: 90 km/hour
  • Let total journey = 36 km
  • And total time taken = 1 hour
  • Time taken for first half = 45 hr
  • Remaining distance = 18 km
  • Remaining time = 15 hr

Speed = 1815 = 90 km/hr

Question 40
Softening of hard water is done by:A. AerationB. BoilingC. Lime sodaD.OzonationE. Ion exchangeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and E only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and E only
  • The correct answer is option (B) – B, C and E only.
  •  
  • To soften hard water, methods are used to remove minerals like calcium and magnesium that cause hardness. Here’s how each option relates to this process:
  •  
  • (A) Aeration:
  • Aeration involves mixing air with water to release gases like carbon dioxide or oxidize dissolved metals. While it can improve water quality, it does not soften hard water.
  •  
  • (B) Boiling:
  • Boiling can help reduce temporary hardness in water by precipitating calcium carbonate, though it is less effective for permanent hardness.
  •  
  • (C) Lime Soda:
  • The lime-soda method is a common chemical method to soften hard water, where lime (calcium hydroxide) and soda ash (sodium carbonate) are added to precipitate calcium and magnesium ions.
  •  
  • (D) Ozonation:
  • Ozonation uses ozone gas to disinfect water and oxidize contaminants, but it does not effectively remove hardness.
  •  
  • (E) Ion exchange:

Ion exchange is a widely-used technique for softening water. In this process, hardness ions (calcium and magnesium) are exchanged with sodium ions using a resin, effectively softening the water.

Question 41
Let L and M be the sum and average of four consecutive odd numbers (a, b, c, and d) respectively, and P and Q be the sum and average of three consecutive even numbers (x, y, and z) respectively. If M= Q-6 and P=L-16, then M=
  • A.32
  • B.34
  • C.36
  • D.30
Correct Answer: 34
  • Let four consecutive odd integers be 2x+1, 2x+3, 2x+5 and 2x+7
  • Then L = 8x + 16
  • M = 2x + 4
  • Also let three consecutive even integers be 2y, 2y+2 and 2y+4
  • Then P = 6y + 6
  • And Q = 2y + 2
  • Now, M = Q-6
  • So, 2x + 4 = 2y + 2 – 6
  • or x – y = - 4 -------------(i)
  • Also, P = L – 16
  • or 6y + 6 = 8x + 16 – 16
  • or 4x – 3y = 3 ------------(ii)
  • Solving (i) and (ii) we get, x = 15 and y = 19

So, M = 34

Question 42
What do people basically want to extract from the communicated message?
  • A.Compulsions
  • B.Meaning
  • C.Synergy
  • D.Behavioural pattern
Correct Answer: Meaning

The correct answer is (B) Meaning.

  •  

In communication, the primary goal for people is to derive meaning from the messages exchanged. Communication involves not just the act of sending and receiving messages, but also the interpretation of those messages. Understanding the meaning helps individuals to make sense of the information presented, leading to effective interaction and comprehension between parties. The other options, such as compulsions, synergy, and behavioral patterns, are not the central focus of what individuals seek in communication; rather, they might be outcomes or contexts of the communication process.

Question 43
Match theList-IwithList-II.List I (Computer components)A. ALUB. Control UnitC. Pen DriveD. Main MemoryList II (Description)I. Immediate access storageII.Carries out arithmetical and logical calculationsIII. Directs the input and output flow in the CPUIV. Secondary / offline storageChoose thecorrectanswer from the options given below:Codes:
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

The correct answer is option (A) - A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I.

  •  
  • A. ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) - II. Carries out arithmetical and logical calculations: The ALU performs mathematical operations and logical operations within the CPU.
  •  
  • B. Control Unit - III. Directs the input and output flow in the CPU: The control unit manages the control signals and directs data movement, handling the flow of information in and out of the CPU.
  •  
  • C. Pen Drive - IV. Secondary/offline storage: A pen drive is a type of secondary storage, used to store data offline.
  •  

D. Main Memory - I. Immediate access storage: Main memory (e.g., RAM) provides immediate, fast access to data for the CPU, allowing quick retrieval for processing.

Question 44
Who among the followingwas the Principal of Bengal National College, established in 1906?
  • A.MotilalGhosh
  • B.AurobindoGhosh
  • C.SatishChandraMukharjee
  • D.BipinChandra Paul
Correct Answer: AurobindoGhosh

The Bengal National College started functioning from 15.Aug.1906 with Sri Aurobindo as its first Principal. In the early stages, he delegated the college's administration to the educator Satish Mukherjee and became deeply involved in political activities. However, when the Bande Mataram (Sedition) Case was filed against him, he resigned from his position in August 1907 to avoid causing any inconvenience to the College authorities. He later resumed his role as Principal following his acquittal in September 1907. During the Alipore Bomb Case in 1908, he resigned from the college permanently at the request of the College authorities.

Question 45
TheNational Knowledge Commission suggested that the proposed national universities should not have:
  • A.Affiliated colleges
  • B.Public funding
  • C.Linkage with industries
  • D.Teaching departments
Correct Answer: Affiliated colleges

The National Knowledge Commission report suggested that the proposed National Universities shall be department-based and shall not have any affiliated colleges.

Question 46
Read the Comprehension and answer the following question:Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in additions to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationship and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self. Inside his or her own consciousness, lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Ethical living is based on:A. our own virtuous attributesB. our behaviour towards other speciesC. our behaviour towards environmentD. material satisfactionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C only
  • B.A and B only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

The correct answer is (C) A, B, and C only.

  •  

The passage describes ethical living as primarily focusing on the quality of our interactions with others, including other species and the environment, and developing virtuous character traits. This includes our own virtuous attributes (A), behavior towards other species (B), and behavior towards the environment (C). Material satisfaction (D) is not highlighted as a basis for ethical living in the passage.

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the following question.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in additions to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationship and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self. Inside his or her own consciousness, lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Which of the following statement is incorrect?
  • A.Culture is static
  • B.All cultures have developed their ethical norms and principles over time
  • C.Rational people of goodwill exist in all cultures
  • D.Culture is dynamic
Correct Answer: Culture is static

The correct answer is (A) Culture is static.

 

The passage suggests that ethical norms and principles have developed across different cultures over time, implying that culture is dynamic and evolves. Thus, the statement "Culture is static" is incorrect, as culture is continually influenced by the values and ethical norms shaped by people over time.

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the following question.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in additions to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationship and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self. Inside his or her own consciousness, lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.For a good leader it is imperative to have
  • A.resources
  • B.daily reflections on his conduct
  • C.higher educational background
  • D.belief in spirituality
Correct Answer: daily reflections on his conduct

The correct answer is (B) daily reflections on his conduct.

  •  

The passage emphasizes that a person aiming for moral leadership must reflect on their own behaviour and consciousness to ensure their actions are ethical and beneficial. This self-reflection helps prevent harm and promotes responsible leadership, aligning with ethical living principles over resources, education level, or spirituality.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the following question.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in additions to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationship and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self. Inside his or her own consciousness, lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Identify the virtuous character traits which help an individual to flourish in life.A. IntegrityB.PsychophancyC. HonestyD. CompassionE. FaithfulnessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C and D only
  • B.A, C and D only
  • C.A, B, C, D, and E
  • D.A, C, D, and E only
Correct Answer: A, C, D, and E only

The correct answer is (D) A, C, D, and E only.

  •  

The passage highlights that virtues like integrity, honesty, faithfulness, and compassion are character traits that help individuals flourish and enhance ethical living. However, "psychophancy" (flattery or servility) is not a virtuous trait that contributes to personal growth or ethical relationships, so it is excluded.

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the following question.Ethical living is concerned primarily with the interpersonal dimension of our behaviour. How do we treat one another individually and in groups and increasingly, other species and the environment? The key here is that morality brings us into contact with others and asks us to consider the quality of that contact. We start asking ourselves: ‘is that the way I should treat someone else?’ ‘Is that the way someone else should treat me?’ Because we have the ability to be critical of our interpersonal behaviour and our interaction with animals, we have the ability to develop codes and norms to guide that behaviour and interaction. Those moral norms and codes, in additions to a set of virtuous character traits, are what we mean when we talk about ethics.Ethics poses questions about how we ought to act in relationship and how we should live with one another. Ethics asks us to consider whether our actions are right or wrong. It also asks us how those character traits that help humans flourish (such as integrity, honest, faithfulness and compassion) play out in everyday living. Ethical norms and principles have developed over time and across cultures, as rational people of goodwill consider human relationships and how human beings act when they are at their best.This everyday ethical reflection must occur before we can effectively confront the larger moral questions. A person who wants to take moral leadership in global issues must take special responsibility for what is going on inside his or her own self. Inside his or her own consciousness, lest the act of leadership create more harm than good. All of us can be leaders for good; the choice is ours.Quality of our interactions in human relationship is gauged by:
  • A.economic status
  • B.social status
  • C.interpersonal behaviour
  • D.educational background
Correct Answer: interpersonal behaviour

The quality of our interactions in human relationships is gauged by option (C) interpersonal behaviour. The passage emphasizes that ethical living is deeply concerned with how we treat others, encouraging us to reflect critically on our interpersonal behaviour to ensure that it aligns with moral norms and virtues, which are key to fostering meaningful, respectful relationships.

Quiz Attempt #119728

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The followingtable shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:DayPersonsABCDEMonday840880480-----560Tuesday720-----1040420820Wednesday560480820850--------Thursday10801020------1260320Friday------9207001020800If the average number of items sold by D on Monday and Tuesday is 490, then the number of items sold by E on Friday is ___________% more than the number of items sold by D on Monday.
  • A.39.76
  • B.42.86
  • C.48.23
  • D.45
Correct Answer: 42.86
  • Let items sold by D on Monday = x
  • Then, x+4202 = 490
  • or x = 560

Required percentage = 800-560560 × 100 = 42.86%

Question 2
The followingtable shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:DayPersonsABCDEMonday840880480-----560Tuesday720-----1040420820Wednesday560480820850--------Thursday10801020------1260320Friday------9207001020800If the ratio of the number of items sold by B and C together on Thursday to the number of items sold by C and E together on the same day is 2 : 1, then the number of items sold by C on Thursday is:
  • A.300
  • B.420
  • C.380
  • D.340
Correct Answer: 380
  • Let items sold by = x
  • Then, x+1020x+320 = 21
  • or 2x + 640 = x + 1020
  • or x = 380

Thus, items sold by C on Thursday = 380

Question 3
The followingtable shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:DayPersonsABCDEMonday840880480-----560Tuesday720-----1040420820Wednesday560480820850--------Thursday10801020------1260320Friday------9207001020800If the number of items sold by C on Thursday is the average of the number of items sold by C on Wednesday and Friday, then the total number of items sold by C on all the five days is:
  • A.3500
  • B.3800
  • C.3400
  • D.3700
Correct Answer: 3800
  • Items sold by C on Thursday = 820+7002 = 760

So, items sold by C on all the five days = 480 + 1040 + 820 + 760 + 700 = 3800

Question 4
The followingtable shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:DayPersonsABCDEMonday840880480-----560Tuesday720-----1040420820Wednesday560480820850--------Thursday10801020------1260320Friday------9207001020800If the total number of items sold by A on all the five days is 3600, then the difference between the number of items sold by A on Monday and Friday is
  • A.640
  • B.450
  • C.420
  • D.440
Correct Answer: 440
  • Items sold by A on Friday = 3600 – (840 + 720 + 560 + 1080) = 400

Difference between the number of items sold by A on Monday and Friday = 840 – 400 = 440

Question 5
The followingtable shows the number of items sold by five persons A-E on five different days (Monday through Friday). Some data is missing in the table that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:DayPersonsABCDEMonday840880480-----560Tuesday720-----1040420820Wednesday560480820850--------Thursday10801020------1260320Friday------9207001020800If the total number of items sold by A and B on all the five days is 4000 and 4400, respectively, then the number of items sold by B on Tuesday is ___________% more than the number of items sold byAon Friday.
  • A.37.5
  • B.23.5
  • C.32.25
  • D.42.5
Correct Answer: 37.5
  • Items sold by B on Tuesday = 4400 – (880 + 480 + 1020 + 920) = 1100
  • Items sold by A on Friday = 4000 – (840 + 720 + 560 + 1080) = 800

Required percentage = 1100-800800 × 100 = 37.5%

Question 6
Benefits of biodiesel over petro-diesel are:A. Biodiesel contains virtually no sulphur.B. Biodiesel emits substantially lower carbon monoxide (CO).C. Biodiesel is a better lubricant than petro-diesel.D. Biodiesel emits significantly lower Oxides of Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) than petro-diesel.E. Particulate emission by biodiesel is much lower thatof petro-diesel.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D only
  • B.B, C, D, E only
  • C.A, B, C, E only
  • D.A, B, D, E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, E only
  • The correct answer is option (C) - A, B, C, E only.
  •  
  • Biodiesel is a renewable, biodegradable fuel derived from natural oils and fats, such as vegetable oil, animal fat, or recycled cooking grease. Unlike petroleum-based diesel, biodiesel is made through a chemical process called transesterification, where fats or oils are converted into fatty acid methyl esters (FAME), the chemical compounds that make up biodiesel.
  •  
  • Biodiesel has several benefits over Petrodiesel, including:
  •  
  • Low Sulfur Content (Statement A): Biodiesel contains virtually no sulfur, which helps reduce the release of sulfur oxides, a pollutant responsible for acid rain.
  •  
  • Lower Carbon Monoxide Emissions (Statement B): Biodiesel produces significantly lower levels of carbon monoxide (CO) emissions compared to petrodiesel, contributing to cleaner air.
  •  
  • Superior Lubrication (Statement C): Biodiesel is a better lubricant than petrodiesel, which helps in reducing engine wear and increasing its lifespan.
  •  
  • Lower Particulate Emissions (Statement E): Biodiesel emits fewer particulates, which helps improve air quality and reduces health risks associated with particulate pollution.

 

Oxides of Nitrogen (NOx) Emissions: Biodiesel tends to emit slightly higher NOx compared to petrodiesel, especially under certain combustion conditions, so statement D is incorrect.

Question 7
According to Classical Indian Schoolof Logic (Nyaya) the argument –"Sound is eternal because it is produced" is fallacious because:
  • A.The middle term instead of being pervaded by the presence of major term is pervaded by its absence.
  • B.The locus of the middle term is impossible.
  • C.The middle term instead of being pervaded by the absence of major term is pervaded by its presence.
  • D.It lacks any major term.
Correct Answer: The middle term instead of being pervaded by the presence of major term is pervaded by its absence.

It is a case of "Viruddha" fallacy.

It is the contradictory middle. The middle term, instead of being pervaded by the presence of the major term, is pervaded by the absence of the major term. Instead of proving the existence of the major term in the minor term, it proves its non-existence therein; e.g., 'sound is eternal, because it is produced'. Here ‘produced, instead of proving the eternality of sound, proves its non-eternality. Here the middle term itself disproves the original proposition and proves its contradictory.

Question 8
Match the List-I withthe List-II.List I (ICT/Tools)A.PadletB. RubricsC.QuizletD.MentimeterList II (Functions)I. Criteria-based assessment and feedbackII. Collaborative digital bulletin broadIII. Real time audience response and pollingIV. Interactive flashcards and study setsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II
Correct Answer: A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • The correct answer is option (B) - A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III.
  •  
  • Padlet (A-II): Padlet is an online tool that acts as a collaborative digital bulletin board. It allows multiple users to post text, images, videos, and other media, making it a suitable tool for collaborative work.
  •  
  • Rubrics (B-I): Rubrics are tools used for criteria-based assessment and feedback, allowing educators to assess and provide structured feedback based on specific criteria.
  •  
  • Quizlet (C-IV): Quizlet is a tool for creating interactive flashcards and study sets, often used by students for memorization and self-study.
  •  

Mentimeter (D-III): Mentimeter is used for real-time audience response and polling, commonly employed to engage participants and gauge opinions during presentations.

Question 9
Arrange the following terms in order of increasing abstractness:A. AlloyB. MetalC. SteelD. MineralChoose the correctanswer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, D, A
  • B.C, A, B, D
  • C.C, A, D, B
  • D.D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: C, A, B, D
  • The correct answer is option (B) - C, A, B, D.
  •  
  • To arrange these terms in order of increasing abstractness, we start with the most specific term and move toward broader categories.
  •  
  • Steel (C): The most specific term, as it refers to a particular type of alloy primarily composed of iron with carbon.
  •  
  • Alloy (A): Broader than steel, it represents any mixture of metals, which includes steel and other metal combinations.
  •  
  • Metal (B): A general category that includes all elemental metals, whether pure or part of an alloy.
  •  
  • Mineral (D): The broadest and most abstract term here, as minerals are naturally occurring substances from which metals may be extracted but can also include non-metallic compounds.
  •  

Thus, the order from the least abstract to the most abstract is Steel → Alloy → Metal → Mineral.

Question 10
The criterion of ‘dependendability’in qualitative research parallels which of the following criteria in quantitative research?
  • A.Objectivity
  • B.Internal validity
  • C.External validity
  • D.Reliability
Correct Answer: Reliability

In qualitative research, the criterion of 'dependability' refers to the consistency of the findings over time and across different contexts, similar to how 'reliability' in quantitative research denotes the consistency and stability of measurement results. Both concepts emphasize the importance of trustworthy and replicable results within their respective methodologies.

Question 11
With reference to different number systems, which of the following statements is true?
  • A.(109)10= (1101001)2
  • B.(123)5= (212)4
  • C.(101)16+ (110)8= (429)10
  • D.(241)6= (131)8
Correct Answer: (123)5= (212)4
  • (123)5 = 3 × 50 + 2 × 51 + 1× 52 = 38

(212)4 = 2 × 40 + 1 × 41 + 2× 42 = 38

Question 12
Under the Universities Act of 1904, universities were given the authority to recognise:
  • A.Schools boards
  • B.Literacy missions
  • C.Elementary schools
  • D.Secondary schools
Correct Answer: Secondary schools

In an attempt to modernise and enhance the Indian educational system, Lord Curzon introduced the Indian Universities Act 1904. In 1902, a commission led by Sir Thomas Raleigh was constituted to study the condition and prospects of universities in India after much consideration. After minor revisions, the advice of the Indian Universities Commission materialised in the Indian Universities Act, which went into effect in March 1904. Under the Indian Universities Act of 1904, secondary schools had to be recognized by the Universities and rules and regulations were framed for this purpose.

Question 13
Suppose H0= Null Hypothesis, Ha= Alternate Hypothesis,µ= population mean, µH0= hypothesized mean. A researcher sets upH0:µ =µH0and Ha:µ<µH0. In this situation, the researcher would apply
  • A.right-tailed test
  • B.left -tailed test
  • C.two-tailed test
  • D.half-tailed test
Correct Answer: left -tailed test

In the given scenario, the null hypothesis (H0) states that the population mean (µ) is equal to the hypothesized mean (µH0), while the alternative hypothesis (Ha) suggests that the population mean is less than the hypothesized mean. Since the alternative hypothesis is testing for a decrease (µ < µH0), it indicates that we are interested in the lower tail of the distribution. Therefore, a left-tailed test is appropriate for this hypothesis setup.

Question 14
Which of the following statement is logically equivalent to the statement - "No liquids are beverages."?1.All non-beverages are non-liquids2.All liquids are non-beverages.3.Some beverages are not liquids4.No beverages are liquids.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.
  • A.1 and 2
  • B.2 and 4
  • C.1 and 3
  • D.3 and 4
Correct Answer: 2 and 4

Statement (ii) is obversion of original statement. Statement (iv) is conversion of original statement.

Question 15
The transfer of learning from one situation to another situation that is conscious and effortful is known as:
  • A.Near transfer
  • B.High-road transfer
  • C.Low-road transfer
  • D.Far transfer
Correct Answer: High-road transfer
  • Transfer of learning, as defined by Perkins and Salomon (1992) occurs “when learning in one context or with one set of materials impacts on performance in another context or with other related materials”.
  •  
  • Low road transfer occurs when the initial learning task and the transfer task are sufficiently similar in context and conditions so there is a high level of automaticity.
  •  

High road transfer requires being able to identify mindful abstractions and connections from the initial learning task and the transfer task. An example of high-road transfer would be learning problem-solving skills in a math class and then consciously applying those skills to develop a budget plan. Here, the person must intentionally reflect on and adapt their math knowledge to a new, real-world context—financial planning—that differs from the original learning environment.

Question 16
What was National Knowledge Commission’s recommendations for minimum gross enrolment ratio to be achieved in higher education by 2015?
  • A.5 percent
  • B.10 percent
  • C.15 percent
  • D.20 percent
Correct Answer: 15 percent
  • The National Knowledge Commission (in year 2005) was an Indian think-tank charged with considering possible policies that might sharpen India's comparative advantage in the knowledge-intensive service sectors. It was constituted on 13 June 2005. In particular, the Commission was to advise the Prime Minister's Office on policy related to education, research institutes and reforms needed to make India competitive in the knowledge economy. The chairman was Sam Pitroda. The Commission submitted its report in 2009. It was a high-level advisory body to the Prime Minister of India.
  •  

One of the Recommendations said that the higher education system needs a massive expansion of opportunities, to around 1500 universities nationwide, that would enable India to attain a gross enrolment ratio of at least 15 % by 2015.

Question 17
Which of the following is correct chronological order of earliest to latest of different acts according to their year of enactment in India?
  • A.The Environment Protection Act, Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act
  • B.Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, The Environment Protection Act, Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act
  • C.Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, The Environment Protection Act, Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act
  • D.Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, The Environment Protection Act
Correct Answer: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, The Environment Protection Act
  • Option D is the correct answer.
  •  
  • Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act 1974
  • Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act 1981

The Environment Protection Act 1986

Question 18
In computers, which of the following statements is true?
  • A.Data matrix printer is a type of non-impact printer
  • B.Laser printer is a type of impact printer
  • C.The resolution of a laser printer is measured in Megabits per second (Mbps)
  • D.Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers
Correct Answer: Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers
  • The correct answer is (D) Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers.
  •  
  • (A) Data matrix printer is a type of non-impact printer:
  • False: A data matrix printer is actually a type of impact printer. Impact printers work by physically striking a ribbon against the paper to produce text and images.
  •  
  • (B) Laser printer is a type of impact printer:
  • False: Laser printers are non-impact printers. They use a laser beam to produce an image on a drum, which is then transferred to paper using toner. This method does not involve striking the paper.
  •  
  • (C) The resolution of a laser printer is measured in Megabits per second (Mbps):
  • False: The resolution of a laser printer is typically measured in dots per inch (DPI), not in Megabits per second. DPI indicates the detail an image holds; the higher the DPI, the better the print quality.
  •  

(D) Data matrix printers are noisy, low quality and slow in comparison to laser printers:

True: Data matrix printers (like dot matrix printers) are known to be noisy due to their impact printing mechanism. They also produce lower quality prints compared to laser printers and tend to print more slowly.

Question 19
The geometric mean of the number 9, 12 and 16 is:
  • A.12.33
  • B.11.66
  • C.12
  • D.12.66
Correct Answer: 12

Geometric Mean = 9×12×163 = 12

Question 20
A school boy, travelling at 3 km/hr,reaches his school 28 minutes late but when he travels at 5 km/hr, he reaches his school 28 minutes early. What distance does he travel every day to reach the school?
  • A.1.6 km
  • B.8 km
  • C.7 km
  • D.9 km
Correct Answer: 7 km
  • Let x be the distance from home to school and t be the time taken
  • Then, x3 = t + 2860 -----------(i)
  • Also, x5 = t - 2860 -----------(ii)
  • Solving (i) and (ii), we get
  • x = 7 and t = 2815

Thus, distance = 7 kms

Question 21
The Western Society considers communication as an instrument of:
  • A.Aggression
  • B.Separation
  • C.Covert operations
  • D.Human relationship
Correct Answer: Human relationship
  • The correct answer is (D) Human relationship.

 

In Western society, communication is primarily viewed as a fundamental tool for building and maintaining human relationships. This perspective emphasizes the role of communication in facilitating understanding, collaboration, and connection between individuals.

Question 22
In the context ofBluetooth and Wi-Fi as wireless communication technologies, which of the following statements are true?A.Bluetooth allows for short-range data transfer between electronic devices, whereas Wi-Fi allows electronic devices to connect to the Internet.B. Bluetooth needs a direct line of sight for data transmission, whereas Wi-Fi does not need it.C. Bluetooth limits the number of devices that can connect at any one time, whereas Wi-Fi is open to more devices and more users.D. Bluetooth does not need a direct line of sight for data transmission, whereas Wi-Fi does need it.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: A and C only
  • The correct answer is option (D) - A and C only.
  •  
  • Statement A: True.
  • Bluetooth is designed for short-range data transfer (typically within 10 meters), connecting devices like headphones, smartphones, and other peripherals. In contrast, Wi-Fi allows electronic devices to connect to the Internet over a wider range, usually covering larger areas like homes and offices.
  •  
  • Statement B: False.
  • Bluetooth does not require a direct line of sight for data transmission. It can transmit data through obstacles like walls, although the range might be affected. Wi-Fi also does not require a direct line of sight, as signals can pass through walls and other barriers.
  •  
  • Statement C: True.
  • Bluetooth has limitations on the number of devices that can connect simultaneously, typically allowing up to 7 devices in a piconet configuration. Wi-Fi, on the other hand, can support many more devices connecting to a single access point.
  •  
  • Statement D: False.

As previously mentioned, Bluetooth does not need a direct line of sight for data transmission, and Wi-Fi does not require it either.

Question 23
A teacher assigns a video lecture for students to watch at home before corning to class. Next day in theclass she engages students in ‘hands-on’experimental activities. Which approach she used in this situation?
  • A.Problem solving
  • B.Collaborative learning
  • C.Flipped classroom
  • D.Personalized learning
Correct Answer: Flipped classroom

A Flipped Classroom is structured around the idea that lecture or direct instruction is not the best use of class time. Instead students encounter information before class, freeing class time for activities that involve higher order thinking.

Question 24
Which of the following came as alternatives to chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) as refrigerants?A.HydrofluorocarbonsB.PerfluorocarbonsC.HydrochlorofluorocarbonsD.HalonsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: A and C only
  • The correct answer is option D - A and C.
  •  
  • Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) were commonly used as refrigerants but were phased out due to their harmful effects on the ozone layer. Alternatives were developed to replace CFCs, primarily focusing on reducing ozone-depleting potential.
  •  
  • A. Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are indeed one of the primary alternatives to CFCs. They do not contain chlorine, which makes them less harmful to the ozone layer, although they are potent greenhouse gases.
  •  

C. Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) were introduced as transitional substitutes for CFCs. They have a lower ozone depletion potential than CFCs, but they are still subject to phase-out under the Montreal Protocol.

Question 25
What will be the value of P in the following number series?0, 3, 26, 255,P, ……………….
  • A.624
  • B.511
  • C.1023
  • D.3124
Correct Answer: 3124
  • The solution is given below.
  •  
  • 11 – 1 = 0
  • 22 – 1 = 3
  • 33 – 1 = 26
  • 44 – 1 = 255

Similarly, 55 – 1 = 3124

Question 26
ThePeriod between 1200 and 1764 AD was remarkable in India for the highest distinction attained by:
  • A.Popular Literature
  • B.Vernacular Literature
  • C.English Literature
  • D.French Literature
Correct Answer: Vernacular Literature

The period between 1200 and 1764 AD in India is notable for the rise of vernacular literature, characterized by the flourishing of literary works in regional languages such as Hindi, Tamil, and Bengali. This era saw the emergence of significant poetry and prose, influenced by movements like Bhakti. In contrast, popular, English, and French literature were less prominent in the Indian context during this time.

Question 27
Identify the correct statement about the quantitative content analysis:
  • A.It can allow a certain amount of longitudinal analysis
  • B.It is an obtrusive method
  • C.It is a very rigid method
  • D.It is a reactive method
Correct Answer: It can allow a certain amount of longitudinal analysis

Quantitative content analysis involves systematically coding and quantifying textual or visual content, allowing researchers to track changes over time. This capability makes it suitable for longitudinal studies, where researchers can analyze content at different points to identify trends or shifts.

Question 28
Communication is continuously:
  • A.evolving
  • B.negative
  • C.stagnant
  • D.subliminal
Correct Answer: evolving
  • The correct answer is option A.
  •  

Communication is continuously evolving due to several factors, including technological advancements, cultural changes, and shifts in societal norms. As new communication platforms and methods emerge, such as social media and instant messaging, the way people interact and share information transforms. This evolution reflects changes in language, expression, and the overall dynamics of interpersonal and mass communication, making it a fluid and adaptable process rather than a stagnant or negative one.

Question 29
“A line is composed of points. Points have no length. Therefore, a line has no length.” Which informal fallacy is committed in this statement?
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Equivocation
  • C.Hasty generalisation
  • D.Slippery slope
Correct Answer: Fallacy of composition

The correct answer is: option (A) - Fallacy of composition.

This statement commits the fallacy of composition, which occurs when one assumes that what is true of individual parts must also be true of the whole. Here, the argument assumes that because a point (a part of a line) has no length, the entire line (composed of points) must also have no length. However, a line is defined by the continuous arrangement of points, giving it length, despite each individual point having none.

Question 30
A way of dealing with conflict in which people express their feelings, ask for what they want, say ‘No’ to things they don’t want, and act in their own best interests, is known as:
  • A.Aggressive style
  • B.Passive style
  • C.Assertive style
  • D.Manipulative style
Correct Answer: Assertive style

The assertive style of communication involves expressing one's feelings and needs openly and honestly while respecting the rights and feelings of others. This approach allows individuals to ask for what they want, say "no" when necessary, and advocate for their own best interests without being aggressive or passive.

Question 31
Temporary hardness in water is also known as:
  • A.Sulphate hardness
  • B.Nitrate hardness
  • C.Chloride hardness
  • D.Carbonate hardness
Correct Answer: Carbonate hardness

Temporary hardness in water is primarily caused by the presence of dissolved bicarbonate minerals, particularly calcium bicarbonate and magnesium bicarbonate. This type of hardness can be removed by boiling the water, which precipitates the bicarbonates as insoluble carbonates. Therefore, it is also referred to as carbonate hardness. In contrast, permanent hardness is caused by sulfate or chloride compounds and cannot be removed by boiling.

Question 32
Thebelief that one can master a situation and produce positive outcomes is known as:
  • A.Self-efficacy
  • B.Self-esteem
  • C.Self-actualisation
  • D.Self-regulation
Correct Answer: Self-efficacy

Self-efficacy refers to an individual's belief in their own ability to successfully execute tasks and manage situations. It is a concept introduced by psychologist Albert Bandura and emphasizes the confidence one has in their capacity to perform specific actions or achieve goals. High self-efficacy can lead to greater motivation, persistence, and resilience in the face of challenges, resulting in positive outcomes.

Question 33
Thecontext in which communication takes place is termed as:
  • A.Historical background
  • B.Objectification
  • C.Environment
  • D.Mediasphere
Correct Answer: Environment

In communication, the term environment refers to the context or setting in which the interaction occurs. This includes physical surroundings, social and cultural contexts, and any situational factors that might influence how messages are interpreted and understood. Unlike "historical background," which deals with past events influencing current interactions, the environment encompasses the immediate factors that affect communication in the present moment. "Objectification" relates to treating a concept as concrete rather than contextual, and "mediasphere" typically refers to the realm of media and communication channels, not the setting for direct interactions.

Question 34
There are three positive numbers. One third of the average of all the three numbers is 8 less than the value of the highest number. If the average of the lowest and the second lowest number is 8, then what is the highest number?
  • A.9
  • B.10
  • C.11
  • D.12
Correct Answer: 11
  • Let the largest number be x
  • Then, x+163×13 = x – 8

Or, x = 11

Question 35
Which of the following are the functions of Indian Council of Social Science Research?A. Encourage delinking of socialsciences from natural sciences.B. Provide scholarship for research in social sciences.C. Give financial support to institutional journals of research.D. Promote social science research.E. Blacklist non-performing social science institutions from time to time.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR) was established in the year of 1969 by the Government of India to promote research in social sciences in the country. ICSSR provide grants for projects, fellowships, international collaboration, organizing seminar / conference, capacity building, survey, publications etc. to promote research in social sciences in India.

Question 36
