Statement II is also correct. Carl Rogers extended his views on therapy as a mode of learning to education. He believed that education should be focused on facilitating personal growth and development, similar to the way therapy fosters self-awareness and self-directed change. Rogers advocated for an educational approach that emphasized empathy, acceptance, and authenticity in the learning process.

Question 9
Givenbelow are two statements.Statement I:Learning is also considered as a social construct.Statement II:Social construct is characterised by development of socially desired behaviour.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both statement I and II are correct.

Both statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement I correctly identify learning as a social construct, meaning that it is influenced by social interactions, cultural contexts, and societal norms. Learning is not solely an individual process but is shaped by the social environment in which it occurs.

 

Statement II also accurately describes social construct as characterized by the development of socially desired behavior. In a social constructivist perspective, individuals acquire knowledge and skills through their interactions with others, and the behaviors that are reinforced and valued by society are more likely to be adopted and internalized by individuals. Therefore, the development of socially desired behavior is an important aspect of social constructivism.

Question 10
MatchList I with the List II:List I (Domains of Teaching Responsibility)A. Planning and PreparationB. InstructionC. Classroom EnvironmentD. Professional ResponsibilitiesList II (Components of Domains)I. Communicating with students.II. Establishing a culture for learning.III. Reflecting on teachingIV. Setting instructional outcomes.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A-IV, B-I, C-III, D-II
  • B.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

The domains of Charlotte Danielson’s framework of teaching are given below.

Therefore, the correct match is as follows.

List I - List II

(Domains of Teaching Responsibility) - (Components of Domains)

A. Planning and Preparation - Setting instructional outcomes

B. Instruction - Communicating with students

C. Classroom Environment - Establishing a culture for learning

D. Professional Responsibilities - Reflecting on teaching

Question 11
Anontological position which asserts that social phenomena and their meanings are continually being accomplished by social which actors refer to.
  • A.Objectivism
  • B.Constructionism
  • C.Interpretivism
  • D.Positivism
Correct Answer: Constructionism

Option B is correct.

Constructionism is an ontological position that asserts that social phenomena and their meanings are continually being constructed or created by social actors through their interactions and interpretations. In other words, social reality is not fixed or objective but is actively produced and shaped by individuals and groups within a social context.

Question 12
The main preoccupation of quantitative researchers are:A. MeasurementB. CausalityC. GeneralizationD. ReplicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.A, B, C and D
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D

Option D is correct.

The main preoccupation of quantitative researchers are:

Measurement: Quantitative researchers focus on accurately measuring variables and concepts in a research study. This involves developing reliable and valid instruments or metrics to assess the phenomena of interest.

Causality: Quantitative researchers often seek to establish causal relationships between variables. They use statistical techniques such as regression analysis and experimental designs to identify causal links and determine the extent to which changes in one variable cause changes in another.

Generalization: Quantitative researchers aim to generalize their findings from a sample to a larger population. They use statistical inference techniques to make predictions or draw conclusions about the population based on the sample data.

Replication: Quantitative researchers emphasize the importance of replication in research. Replication involves repeating a study to validate its findings and ensure the reliability and robustness of the results. Replication also allows researchers to assess the generalizability of findings across different contexts or populations.

Question 13
Identify the bibliographic software among the following.A.TurnitinB. EndNoteC. Reference ManagerD.MendeleyChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, B and D only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

Option B is correct.

The bibliographic software are specifically designed for managing references and citations in academic writing which are as follows:

EndNote is a popular bibliographic software used for organizing references, creating bibliographies, and managing citations in academic writing. It allows users to store and organize references, automatically generate citations in various citation styles, and integrate with word processing software for seamless manuscript preparation.

Reference Manager is another bibliographic software developed by the same company as EndNote. It offers similar functionalities for managing references and citations in academic writing.

Mendeley is also a bibliographic software that enables users to organize references, annotate PDFs, collaborate with peers, and generate citations and bibliographies. It is known for its social networking features, allowing researchers to share and discover research papers within the Mendeley community.

Question 14
The meanand standard deviation of 70 observations are 47 and 9, respectively. If 3 is subtracted from each observation, the new mean and standard deviation will be.
  • A.44, 6
  • B.44, 9
  • C.47, 6
  • D.44, 3
Correct Answer: 44, 9

When a constant is subtracted from each observation, the mean also decreases by that constant.

New mean = Old mean – 3 = 47 – 3 = 44

 

Standard Deviation:

Subtracting a constant from each observation does not directly affect the standard deviation. However, when the data is shifted, the standard deviation remains the same. So, the new mean is 44, and the standard deviation remains 9.

Question 15
Given below are two statements.Statement I:SPSS is an open-source software for data analysis.Statement II:Turnitinis a very useful software for statistical data analysis.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer. From the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.

Option B is correct.

Statement I is incorrect. SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) is not an open-source software. It is a proprietary software package developed by IBM for statistical analysis and data management. While SPSS is widely used in academic and research settings, it is licensed software and not freely available as open-source software.

Statement II is also incorrect. Turnitin is not a software for statistical data analysis. Instead, Turnitin is a plagiarism detection tool commonly used in educational institutions to check the originality of written work by comparing it against a vast database of academic and web sources. It is not designed for statistical analysis or data manipulation.

Question 16
Mirroring anotherperson’s non-verbal behaviour facilitates
  • A.Resistance
  • B.Restriction
  • C.Regression
  • D.Compliance
Correct Answer: Compliance

Option D is correct.

Mirroring another person's non-verbal behavior, also known as non-verbal mimicry or mirroring, involves subtly imitating or synchronizing one's body language, gestures, facial expressions, tone of voice, or other non-verbal cues to match those of the other person. This behavior is often done unconsciously and can occur during social interactions, such as conversations or negotiations.

Mirroring another person's non-verbal behavior typically facilitates compliance, as it enhances interpersonal rapport and increases the likelihood of agreement or cooperation.

Question 17
Buddhism contains awell-developed model of ________ communication.
  • A.Business
  • B.Mass
  • C.Interpersonal
  • D.Organizational
Correct Answer: Interpersonal

Option C is correct.

Buddhism contains teachings and principles that encompass various aspects of human interaction, including communication. While Buddhism does not explicitly focus on modern concepts such as business, mass, or organizational communication, it does provide guidance on interpersonal communication within the context of personal relationships, community interactions, and spiritual development.

Question 18
Which ofthe following are identified as non-verbal practices of communication?A. Mimicking speechesB. AccentC. PostureD. GaitE. DressChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

Option C is correct.

Posture refers to the positioning of the body, including the alignment of the spine, limbs, and overall body stance. Posture is a significant aspect of non-verbal communication as it can convey emotions, attitudes, and intentions. For example, standing upright may convey confidence, while slouching may convey boredom or disinterest.

Gait refers to the manner of walking or the distinctive pattern of movement while walking. Like posture, gait is a non-verbal cue that can convey information about a person's mood, personality, or physical condition. For instance, a brisk, purposeful gait may indicate confidence or urgency, while a slow, shuffling gait may suggest fatigue or discomfort.

Dress refers to the clothing and attire worn by individuals, which can communicate social status, cultural identity, personal style, and adherence to norms or expectations. Clothing choices can convey messages about professionalism, formality, or group affiliation without the need for verbal communication.

Question 19
TheShannon and Weaver model of communication has which of the following characteristics?A. It is linear.B. It focuses on transmission of information.C. It is concerned with reproduction of messages from one point to another.D. It offers a meta model of communication.E. The feedback component is circular.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

The Shannon and Weaver model of communication includes the following characteristics:

 

A. It is linear: The model describes communication as a linear process, moving from a sender to a receiver.

 

B. It focuses on transmission of information: The model emphasizes the transmission of messages from one point to another, with a focus on the technical aspects of communication.

 

C. It is concerned with reproduction of messages from one point to another: The model is primarily concerned with how messages are encoded, transmitted, and decoded between sender and receiver.

 

Option D is incorrect because the Shannon and Weaver model does not offer a meta model of communication. Option E is incorrect because the feedback component in the Shannon and Weaver model is not circular; it is depicted as a separate element that follows the linear flow of communication.

Question 20
Given below are two statements.Statement I:Communication is a symbolic process and as such depends upon symbols that are both arbitrary and conventional.Statement II:Different symbols cannot be selected to represent an object or idea to communicate.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.

Option C is correct.

Statement I is correct. Communication involves the use of symbols, such as words, gestures, images, or sounds, to convey meaning. These symbols are arbitrary, meaning there is no inherent connection between the symbol and its meaning, and conventional, meaning they are agreed upon within a particular culture or community. For example, the word "tree" is a symbol used to represent the concept of a tree, but there is no inherent connection between the word and the actual object.

 

Statement II is incorrect. In communication, different symbols can indeed be selected to represent the same object or idea. For example, the concept of love can be represented by various symbols such as a heart shape, the word "love," a red rose, or an embrace. The selection of symbols may vary depending on cultural norms, personal preferences, or contextual factors.

Question 21
Aperson buys a mobile phone from a shop for ₹7800.00. The shopkeeper makes a profit of 20% at the cost price. What is the cost price of the mobile phone?
  • A.₹6500
  • B.₹6240
  • C.₹5860
  • D.₹6800
Correct Answer: ₹6500

CP = 78001.2 = Rs. 6500

Question 22
Tworailway stations A and B are 380 km apart. Train-1 leaves station A at 7:00 AM moving with a speed of 80 km/hour towards B. After half an hour, Train-2 leaves station B towards A moving with the speed of 90 km/hour. At what time the 2 trains will cross each other?
  • A.8:45 AM
  • B.9:00 AM
  • C.9:30 AM
  • D.10:15 AM
Correct Answer: 9:30 AM

When train – 2 left from station B, train – 1 covered distance of 40 km.

Remaining difference 340 km will be covered by train – 1 and train – 2 travelling with relative speed.

Time the trains will meet = 34090+80 = 2 hrs

Thus, they will meet at 9:30 AM

Question 23
In a certain code, ‘DELHI’ is coded as 19 and ‘CHENNAI’ is coded as 27. How will ‘GUWAHATI’ be coded in the above code?
  • A.30
  • B.45
  • C.75
  • D.25
Correct Answer: 45

DELHI = 4+5+12+8+92 = 19

CHENNAI = 3+8+5+14+14+1+92 = 27

Similarly

GUWAHATI = 7+21+23+1+8+1+20+92 = 45

Question 24
The monthly expenses (in thousandsRs.) of a family during a year from January to December months were 16, 19, 18, 23, 24, 28, 26, 19, 19, 22, 20 and 18, respectively.In which of the months the deviation of the expenses from the average monthly expense of the year was the least?
  • A.February, August, and September
  • B.June and July
  • C.March, August, and September
  • D.October and November
Correct Answer: October and November

Average expense = 16+19+18+23+24+28+26+19+19+22+20+1812 = 21

Thus, the deviation was least in October and November month.

Question 25
The firstterm in an arithmetic series of 100 terms is 7. If the last term is 205, what is the 71st term of the series?
  • A.157
  • B.151
  • C.147
  • D.161
Correct Answer: 147

7 + 99d = 205

or d = 2

71st term = a + 70d

= 7 + 70 × 2

= 147

Question 26
As per square of opposition, which of the following propositions are contradictories?A. All birds are apes.B. No birds are apes.C. Some birds are apes.D. Some birds are not apes.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.C and D only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

B “No birds are apes” and C “Some birds are apes” are contradictory.

Question 27
Which of the following statements are logically equivalent?A. All non-apes are non-monkeys.B. No apes are non-monkeys.C. No monkeys are non-apes.D. All monkeys are apes.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.Codes:
  • A.A, C and D only
  • B.B and D only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.B and C only
Correct Answer: A, C and D only

Statement ‘A’ and Statement ‘C’ are contra-position and obversion respectively of statement ‘D’.

Question 28
As per square of opposition, if the statement- “All apes are mammals” is given as true, which of the following statements can be immediately inferred to be false?A. No apes are mammals.B. Some apes are mammals.C. Some mammals are apes.D. Some apes are not mammals.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A only
  • B.D only
  • C.A and D only
  • D.A, C and D only
Correct Answer: A and D only

If type A is true, then type O and type E is false. Therefore, correct answer is Option C, i.e., A and D only.

Question 29
“Either youlet me go to Las Vegas for a vacation or I will be miserable for the rest of my life. I am sure you don’t want to see me miserable, so you have a clear decision to allow me to go for a vacation to Las Vegas.” Which fallacy is committed in this statement?
  • A.Appeal to force
  • B.False Dichotomy
  • C.False Cause
  • D.Complex Question
Correct Answer: False Dichotomy

False Dichotomy, also known as the false dilemma fallacy, occurs when someone presents a situation as having only two alternatives or options when in fact there are more. In the statement given, the person presents the situation as if the only options are letting them go to Las Vegas for a vacation or they will be miserable for the rest of their life. This creates a false sense of limited options, ignoring other possible solutions or compromises.

Question 30
Given below are two statements, one is labelled as Assertion (A) and other one labelled as Reason (R).Assertion ‘A’:According to classical Indian view of logic, the argument- ‘Fire is cold, because it is a substance’ is fallacious.Reason ‘R’:As per classical Indian view of logic, the argument- ‘Fire is cold, because it is a substance’ involves the middle term that is not exclusive.In light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both (A) and (R) are correct and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).
  • B.Both (A) and (R) are correct, but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A).
  • C.(A) is correct, but (R) is not correct.
  • D.(A) is not correct, but (R) is correct.
Correct Answer: (A) is correct, but (R) is not correct.

Reason is incorrect because it is the non-inferentially contradicted middle. Here the middle term is contradicted by some other pramäna and not by inference. It cannot prove the major term which is disproved by another stronger source of valid knowledge; e.g., ‘fire is cold, because it is a substance. Here the middle term ‘substance becomes contradicted because its major term ‘coldness is directly contradicted by perception. This is known as Bâdhita fallacy.

Question 31
The transmission time required for sending 512-byte packet using 56 kilobits (1 kilo = 1000) per second modern is about.
  • A.7 milliseconds
  • B.43 milliseconds
  • C.73 milliseconds
  • D.80 milliseconds
Correct Answer: 73 milliseconds

Time required = 512×856000 = 0.073 seconds = 73 milliseconds.

Question 32
If(P)8represents the number P in base 8 number system, then(124)8+(165)8=
  • A.(201)8
  • B.(289)10
  • C.(274)8
  • D.(311)8
Correct Answer: (311)8

(124)8 = 4 × 80 + 2 × 81 + 1 × 82 = 4 + 16 + 64 = 84

(165)8 = 5 × 80 + 6 × 81 + 1 × 82 = 5 + 48 + 64 = 117

(124)8+  (165)8= 84 + 117 = 201

 

Now, 2018 = 25 remainder 1

258 = 3 remainder 1

38 = 0 remainder 3

Thus, 201 = (311)8

Question 33
Given below are two statements.Statement I:The Internet is not regulated in India; therefore, the information may be biased or inaccurate.Statement II:The Internet is one of the services offered by World Wide Web (WWW).In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.

Internet in India, like in many countries, is not heavily regulated in terms of content control. This lack of strict regulation can indeed lead to the spread of biased or inaccurate information. However, it's essential to note that there are certain laws and regulations in place to address specific types of content, such as hate speech, defamation, and incitement to violence. So statement I is correct.

 

The World Wide Web (WWW) is not a service offered by the Internet; rather, it is a system of interconnected hypertext documents and resources accessed via the Internet. The Internet itself is a global network infrastructure that facilitates the transmission of data between devices worldwide, enabling various services and applications beyond just the WWW. Therefore, statement II is incorrect.

Question 34
Which of the following statements is are true regarding ICT?A. Encryption is the scrambling of data, thereby destroying computer viruses and preventing unauthorised access to computer systems.B. Microblog is very much restricted on the size of post and is very difficult to customize.C. LAN always uses wireless technology to transmit data.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A only
  • B.B only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: B only

Encryption is scrambling of data to make it unreadable to unauthorized users, but it is primarily used to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of data, rather than destroying computer viruses. Encryption helps secure data during transmission and storage, but it does not directly deal with computer viruses. So statement A is incorrect.

 

Microblogging platforms, such as Twitter, typically impose limitations on the length of posts, commonly known as tweets. Tweets on Twitter, for example, are limited to a specific character count (280 characters as of the time of writing). Additionally, microblogging platforms often have limited customization options compared to other social media platforms, emphasizing brevity and simplicity in communication. So statement B is correct.

 

LAN (Local Area Network) refers to a network that connects devices within a limited geographical area, such as a home, office, or campus. While LANs can utilize wireless technology (Wi-Fi) for data transmission, they can also employ wired connections (Ethernet) depending on the infrastructure and requirements of the network. LANs can utilize a combination of wired and wireless technologies based on factors such as reliability, bandwidth, and security. Therefore, statement C is incorrect.

Question 35
Match List I with the List II:List I (Input device)A. Bar Code readerB. MicrophoneC. ScannerD. MouseList II (Most appropriate use)I. To enter hard copy image into a computer.II. To select items from a menu in a software.III. To input data from a food item in a mall at a Point-Of-Sale (POS) terminal.IV. To create a voice over a presentation.
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

Bar code readers are commonly used at Point-of-Sale (POS) terminals in malls and retail stores to scan barcodes on products for quick and accurate data input during transactions.

 

Microphones are used to capture audio input, such as voice recordings or live speech, and can be utilized to create voiceovers for presentations, videos, or multimedia content.

 

Scanners are input devices used to convert physical documents, images, or photographs into digital formats, allowing them to be stored, edited, and manipulated on a computer.

 

A mouse is a pointing device used to navigate graphical user interfaces (GUIs) and interact with software applications by clicking on menus, icons, buttons, and other graphical elements.

Question 36
Which of the following pollutants is responsible for causing blue baby disease?
  • A.Mercury
  • B.Particulate Matter
  • C.Nitrates
  • D.Sulphur dioxide
Correct Answer: Nitrates

Blue baby disease, or methemoglobinemia, is a condition affecting infants, causing a bluish tint to their skin due to reduced blood oxygen-carrying capacity. This condition, characterized by cyanosis and symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and lethargy, is caused by the conversion of nitrates in water, especially groundwater, into nitrites in the body. Nitrites then react with hemoglobin, forming methemoglobin, which cannot effectively transport oxygen, resulting in low blood oxygen levels and the characteristic blue discoloration of the skin.

Question 37
Which of the following is not responsible for the destruction of ozone layer?
  • A.CFC
  • B.Halons
  • C.Dioxins
  • D.HCFC
Correct Answer: Dioxins

Dioxins are not responsible for the destruction of the ozone layer. Ozone layer depletion is primarily caused by substances like chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), halons, and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs), which release chlorine and bromine atoms into the stratosphere, where they catalytically destroy ozone molecules. Dioxins, on the other hand, are primarily known for their environmental and health effects, such as being toxic pollutants, but they do not contribute to ozone layer depletion.

Question 38
Given below are two statements.Statement I:Under Montreal Protocol, developed and developing countries have same timetable for phasing out of Ozone Depleting Substances (ODS).Statement II:Under Montreal Protocol, developing countries are referred to as ‘Article 5 Countries’.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.

Under the Montreal Protocol, developed and developing countries do not have the same timetable for phasing out Ozone Depleting Substances (ODS). Developing countries are given longer timelines and more flexibility to phase out these substances compared to developed countries. So statement I is incorrect.

 

Developing countries are often referred to as 'Article 5 Countries' under the Montreal Protocol, as they are covered under Article 5 of the agreement, which provides them with certain exemptions and financial assistance to help them comply with the protocol's requirements. Therefore, statement II is correct.

Question 39
Which ofthe following are true about the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs)?A. MDGs have 8 goals.B. MDGs have 40 targets.C. MDGs were to be achieved by the year 2015.D. MDGs were the successor of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.B, C and D only
Correct Answer: A and C only

The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were established following the Millennium Summit of the United Nations in 2000. These goals were set to address key global challenges such as poverty, hunger, education, gender equality, health, and environmental sustainability. MDGs have 8 goals. So statement A is correct.

 

While the MDGs have 8 goals, they are accompanied by 21 targets. These targets are specific, measurable objectives that provide a framework for monitoring progress towards achieving the goals. So statement B is false.

 

he MDGs were set to be achieved by the year 2015. This timeline provided a sense of urgency to the global community to work towards meeting the goals and improving the lives of millions of people around the world. Therefore statement C is true.

 

The MDGs were succeeded by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, which were adopted by the United Nations in 2015. The SDGs build on the progress made under the MDGs and expand the scope to address a wider range of sustainable development issues, including poverty, inequality, climate change, and peace and justice. So, statement D is false.

Question 40
Which of the following are examples of Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs)?A. DioxinsB. Poly-Chlorinated Benzenes (PCBs)C. FormaldehydeD.OrganoChlorine PesticidesE. FuransChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, C and E only
  • B.A, B, D and E only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.B, C and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E only

Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) are organic compounds that are resistant to environmental degradation through chemical, biological, and photolytic processes. These pollutants persist in the environment, can travel long distances through air and water, accumulate in the fatty tissues of living organisms, and have harmful impacts on human health and the environment.

 

Examples of POPs include certain pesticides (such as DDT), industrial chemicals (such as polychlorinated biphenyls or PCBs), and unintentional by-products of industrial processes (such as dioxins and furans). These substances are of concern due to their potential to cause adverse effects, including cancer, reproductive disorders, and disruption of the immune and endocrine systems.

 

From the options given, dioxins, PCBs, organochlorine pesticides and furans are examples.

Question 41
BeforeIndependence, the Lady Irwin College, Delhi was set up for teaching?
  • A.Civil engineering
  • B.Fine arts
  • C.Horticulture
  • D.Educationalresearch
Correct Answer: Educationalresearch

Lady Irwin College, Delhi, was established before Independence, specifically in 1932. It was founded to focus on educational research and training in the field of home science and related disciplines. The college has historically been known for its contributions to the field of education, particularly in areas related to home science, nutrition, and family welfare. Therefore, option D is the correct answer.

Question 42
LordAuckland supported the idea of establishing _________ in places with a large population.
  • A.Community colleges
  • B.Central colleges
  • C.Technical colleges
  • D.Science colleges
Correct Answer: Central colleges

Option B is correct.

During the British colonial period in India, there was a recognition of the need for higher education institutions to cater to the growing population and demand for education. Lord Auckland, who served as Governor-General of India from 1836 to 1842, supported the establishment of central colleges in areas with significant populations.

Central colleges were envisioned as educational institutions that would serve as centers of higher learning and provide a wide range of academic disciplines to students. These colleges aimed to offer comprehensive education, including arts, sciences, humanities, and professional studies, to meet the diverse needs of students and society.

Question 43
TheUniversity ofVikramasilawas a well-known centre of
  • A.Arabic language
  • B.Chinsesphilosophy
  • C.Tantric Buddhism
  • D.Japanese art
Correct Answer: Tantric Buddhism

Option C is correct.

The University of Vikramasila was one of the most renowned centers of learning in ancient India, particularly during the Pala dynasty rule from the late 8th century to the early 12th century. Located in present-day Bihar, India, Vikramasila University was a major seat of Buddhist learning and played a significant role in the development and propagation of Tantric Buddhism.

Tantric Buddhism, also known as Vajrayana Buddhism, is a form of Mahayana Buddhism that emphasizes the use of rituals, visualizations, and esoteric practices to attain enlightenment. Vikramasila University was instrumental in the study and dissemination of Tantric Buddhist teachings, attracting scholars, monks, and students from various parts of India and beyond.

Question 44
Which of the following are autonomous research institutions under various government departments and agencies in India?A. Council of Scientific and Industrial Research.B. Indian Council of Social Science Research.C. Indian Institute of Astrophysics.D. Institute of Civil Research, India.E. Indian Biological Sciences and Research InstituteChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

Option A is correct.

CSIR is an autonomous research institution under various government departments and agencies in India. It is the premier industrial R&D organization in India and operates under the Ministry of Science and Technology.

ICSSR is also an autonomous research institution under various government departments and agencies in India. It is responsible for promoting and funding research in the social sciences and operates under the Ministry of Education.

The Indian Institute of Astrophysics is an autonomous research institution under various government departments and agencies in India. It is dedicated to research in astronomy, astrophysics, and related fields and operates under the Department of Science and Technology.

Question 45
Given below are two statements.Statement I:The National Accreditation Board as per NEP report of 2016, must oversee the entire process of accreditation, set standards and define guidelines for the purpose.Statement II:It can license the private agencies (preferable non-profit ones), who will do the actual evaluation of academic institutions.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both statement I and II are correct.

Option A is correct.

Statement I is correct. The NEP of 2016 emphasized the importance of accreditation in ensuring quality education and proposed the establishment of a National Accreditation Board to regulate and oversee the accreditation process for educational institutions. The board would be responsible for setting standards, defining guidelines, and ensuring the quality of accreditation processes.

Statement II is also correct. According to the NEP report of 2016, the National Accreditation Board would have the authority to license private agencies, preferably non-profit ones, to conduct the actual evaluation of academic institutions. These agencies would assess institutions based on the standards and guidelines set by the accreditation board, thereby ensuring impartial and rigorous evaluation processes.

Question 46
Read thepassage given below and answer the following questions.Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the ocean. As diverse know, thousands of beautiful fish,mollusksand urchins are among the amazing marine life that live among coral reefs. In fact, the corals themselves are also marine animals. Almost a thousand coral species currently exist in fantastic shapes ranging from mushroom to moose, antlers, cabbages,tabletops, wire strands and fluted pillars.With the majority of humankind living in coastal regions, many people depend on living coral reefs for food and protection from storms and erosions, as well as the additional benefit of medical research, tourism, and natural beauty. Coral reefs contribute about 25% to the total fish catch in developing countries, providing food for one billion people in Asia alone. Unfortunately, human activities, including those associated with global warming are threatening these animals. Increasing sea temperatures stress corals and causes damage.World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is working to develop and test conservation strategies to better protect coral reefs while also working to stop global warming, the root cause of their destruction.Coral reefs are important because.A. They contribute 35% of the total fish catch and developing countries.B. Many people depend on them for food.C. They provide protection from storms and erosions.D. They provide food for one billion people in Asia.E. They are the cause of global warming.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.B, C and D only
  • B.A and E only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.B and D only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

Option A is correct.

As per the passage, coral reefs are important because many people depend on them for food, they provide protection from storms and erosions and they provide food for one billion people in Asia.

Question 47
Read thepassage given below and answer the following questions.Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the ocean. As diverse know, thousands of beautiful fish,mollusksand urchins are among the amazing marine life that live among coral reefs. In fact, the corals themselves are also marine animals. Almost a thousand coral species currently exist in fantastic shapes ranging from mushroom to moose, antlers, cabbages,tabletops, wire strands and fluted pillars.With the majority of humankind living in coastal regions, many people depend on living coral reefs for food and protection from storms and erosions, as well as the additional benefit of medical research, tourism, and natural beauty. Coral reefs contribute about 25% to the total fish catch in developing countries, providing food for one billion people in Asia alone. Unfortunately, human activities, including those associated with global warming are threatening these animals. Increasing sea temperatures stress corals and causes damage.World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is working to develop and test conservation strategies to better protect coral reefs while also working to stop global warming, the root cause of their destruction.Coral reefsare being threatened because ofA. Decreasing Sea temperaturesB. Human activitiesC. Global warmingD. Rising sea levels.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A and B only
Correct Answer: B and C only

Option C is correct.

As per the passage, coral reefs are being threatened because of human activities and global warming.

Question 48
Read thepassage given below and answer the following questions.Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the ocean. As diverse know, thousands of beautiful fish,mollusksand urchins are among the amazing marine life that live among coral reefs. In fact, the corals themselves are also marine animals. Almost a thousand coral species currently exist in fantastic shapes ranging from mushroom to moose, antlers, cabbages,tabletops, wire strands and fluted pillars.With the majority of humankind living in coastal regions, many people depend on living coral reefs for food and protection from storms and erosions, as well as the additional benefit of medical research, tourism, and natural beauty. Coral reefs contribute about 25% to the total fish catch in developing countries, providing food for one billion people in Asia alone. Unfortunately, human activities, including those associated with global warming are threatening these animals. Increasing sea temperatures stress corals and causes damage.World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is working to develop and test conservation strategies to better protect coral reefs while also working to stop global warming, the root cause of their destruction.Which of the following are true about coral reefs?A. Presently nearly 1000 coral species exist.B. Coral reefs are non-living.C. Fish, molluscs and urchins live among coral reefs.D. Cabbage grow on coral reefs.E. Because of their beauty they are attract tourists.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.

  • B.C, D and E only

  • D.A, C and E only

Presently nearly 1000 coral species exist

Fish, molluscs and urchins live among coral reefs.

Because of their beauty they are attract tourists.

Question 49
Read thepassage given below and answer the following questions.Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the ocean. As diverse know, thousands of beautiful fish,mollusksand urchins are among the amazing marine life that live among coral reefs. In fact, the corals themselves are also marine animals. Almost a thousand coral species currently exist in fantastic shapes ranging from mushroom to moose, antlers, cabbages,tabletops, wire strands and fluted pillars.With the majority of humankind living in coastal regions, many people depend on living coral reefs for food and protection from storms and erosions, as well as the additional benefit of medical research, tourism, and natural beauty. Coral reefs contribute about 25% to the total fish catch in developing countries, providing food for one billion people in Asia alone. Unfortunately, human activities, including those associated with global warming are threatening these animals. Increasing sea temperatures stress corals and causes damage.World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is working to develop and test conservation strategies to better protect coral reefs while also working to stop global warming, the root cause of their destruction.Which of the following organizations is working towards the protection of coral reefs?
  • A.UNO
  • B.WWF
  • C.UNESCO

Question 50
Read thepassage given below and answer the following questions.Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the ocean. As diverse know, thousands of beautiful fish,mollusksand urchins are among the amazing marine life that live among coral reefs. In fact, the corals themselves are also marine animals. Almost a thousand coral species currently exist in fantastic shapes ranging from mushroom to moose, antlers, cabbages,tabletops, wire strands and fluted pillars.With the majority of humankind living in coastal regions, many people depend on living coral reefs for food and protection from storms and erosions, as well as the additional benefit of medical research, tourism, and natural beauty. Coral reefs contribute about 25% to the total fish catch in developing countries, providing food for one billion people in Asia alone. Unfortunately, human activities, including those associated with global warming are threatening these animals. Increasing sea temperatures stress corals and causes damage.World Wildlife Fund (WWF) is working to develop and test conservation strategies to better protect coral reefs while also working to stop global warming, the root cause of their destruction.Given below are two statements.Statement I:All coral reaves have only one shape.Statement II:Global warming is threatening the coral reefs.In light of the above statements choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Both statement I and statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct

As per the passage, statement I is incorrect, but statement II is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119731

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of candidates (Boys and Girls) and the number of boys who appeared in an entrance examination from six different cities A-F. A total of 78,000 candidates appeared from all the six cities, in which the number of boys was 24000. Based on the data in the table answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage DistributionCandidates who appeared in the examBoys who appeared in the examA17%23%B13.5%20%C15%17%D20%10%E8.5%21%F26%9%What is the total number of girls who appeared from city A?
  • A.6420
  • B.6880
  • C.7300
  • D.7740
Correct Answer: 7740

Candidates appeared from city A = 78000 × 0.17 = 13260

Girls appeared from city A = 13260 – 23% of 24000 = 7740

Question 2
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of candidates (Boys and Girls) and the number of boys who appeared in an entrance examination from six different cities A-F. A total of 78,000 candidates appeared from all the six cities, in which the number of boys was 24000. Based on the data in the table answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage DistributionCandidates who appeared in the examBoys who appeared in the examA17%23%B13.5%20%C15%17%D20%10%E8.5%21%F26%9%What is the difference between the number of boys and the number of girls who appeared in the exam from city E?
  • A.3450
  • B.3500
  • C.3550
  • D.3650
Correct Answer: 3450

Number of candidates from City E = 8.5% of 78000 = 6630

Number of Boys from City E = 21% of 24000 = 5040

Number of Girls appeared from City E = 6630 – 5040 = 1590

Required difference = 5040 – 1590 = 3450

Question 3
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of candidates (Boys and Girls) and the number of boys who appeared in an entrance examination from six different cities A-F. A total of 78,000 candidates appeared from all the six cities, in which the number of boys was 24000. Based on the data in the table answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage DistributionCandidates who appeared in the examBoys who appeared in the examA17%23%B13.5%20%C15%17%D20%10%E8.5%21%F26%9%Number of girls who appeared from city C is approximately _____________ % of the number of candidates who appeared from city D.
  • A.45
  • B.49
  • C.54
  • D.57
Correct Answer: 49

Number of Candidates appeared from city C = 15% of 78000 = 11700

Number of Candidates appeared from city D = 20% of 78000 = 15600

Number of girls appeared from city C = 11700 – 17% of 24000

= 11700 – 4080 = 7620

Required percentage = 762015600 × 100 ≈ 49%

Question 4
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of candidates (Boys and Girls) and the number of boys who appeared in an entrance examination from six different cities A-F. A total of 78,000 candidates appeared from all the six cities, in which the number of boys was 24000. Based on the data in the table answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage DistributionCandidates who appeared in the examBoys who appeared in the examA17%23%B13.5%20%C15%17%D20%10%E8.5%21%F26%9%Number of boys who appeared from city A is __________ % more than that from city B.
  • A.8
  • B.12
  • C.15
  • D.18
Correct Answer: 15

Required percentage = 23-2020 × 100 = 15%

Question 5
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of the number of candidates (Boys and Girls) and the number of boys who appeared in an entrance examination from six different cities A-F. A total of 78,000 candidates appeared from all the six cities, in which the number of boys was 24000. Based on the data in the table answer the questions that follow.CityPercentage DistributionCandidates who appeared in the examBoys who appeared in the examA17%23%B13.5%20%C15%17%D20%10%E8.5%21%F26%9%Number of girls who appeared from city F is approximately ___________ % of the number of girls who appeared from the six cities together.
  • A.31.55
  • B.32.55
  • C.33.55
  • D.34.55
Correct Answer: 33.55
