Correct Answer: A and C only

Intra-personal communication involves communication within oneself. The two basic psychological functions of intra-personal communication are:

 

(i) Internalisation of culturally organised ways of thinking: This refers to the process of internalizing and assimilating cultural norms, values, and beliefs, which influence one's thoughts, attitudes, and behaviors.

 

(ii) Regulation of one's own mental activity: This involves the ability to regulate and control one's thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, which is essential for self-awareness, self-reflection, and self-management.

 

Thus, option B is correct.

Question 19
Given below are two statements:Statement I:In mass communication, the message is rapid and public.Statement II:New technology has blurred the distinction between inter-personal communication and mass communication.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct, but statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I incorrect, but statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both statement I and Statement II are correct

Both statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I: In mass communication, the message often reaches a large audience and can be disseminated rapidly through various channels such as television, radio, or the internet. Additionally, mass communication messages are typically intended for public consumption, rather than being directed at specific individuals. Therefore, statement I is correct.

 

Statement II: New technology, such as social media and digital platforms, has indeed blurred the distinction between interpersonal communication and mass communication. These technologies allow individuals to communicate with large audiences in a manner that resembles interpersonal communication, thereby altering the traditional boundaries between the two forms of communication. Therefore, statement II is also correct.

Question 20
Match List IwithList IIList - I (Communication model)A. LinearB. CircularC. Non-linearD. MetaList - II (Description)I. Communication as interactionII. Communication as transactionIII. Model of Communication modelsIV. Communication as action
  • A.A-I, B -II, C - III, D - IV
  • B.A-II, B - III, C - IV, D - I
  • C.A- III, B - IV. C - I, D - II
  • D.A- IV, B - I, C - II, D - III
Correct Answer: A- IV, B - I, C - II, D - III

The correct match is as follows.

List - I – List II –

(Communication model) - (Description)

A. Linear - Communication as action

Human Communication as Action Human communication is linear, with meaning sent or transferred from source to receiver.

Model of Communication as Action

 

B. Circular - "Communication as interaction"

Human communication occurs as the receiver of the message responds to the source through feedback.

 

Model of Communication as Interaction

 

C. Non-linear - "Communication as transaction"

Human communication is simultaneously interactive. Meaning is created on the basis of mutual, concurrent sharing of ideas and feelings. This transactive model most accurately describes human communication.

 

Model of Communication as transaction

 

D. Meta - Model of Communication models

Meta represents the model of communication models, which can encompass various communication theories and frameworks. This corresponds to "Model of Communication models."

Question 21
It takes 10 men to finish a work in 2 days. Four men started to execute the work but after one day, 3 of them left, how many days it will take the one man to finish the remaining work?
  • A.12 days
  • B.14 days
  • C.15 days
  • D.16 days
Correct Answer: 16 days

Let total work = 20 units

10 men can finish a work in 2 days.

1 man can do it in 30 days and 4 men can do it in 5 days.

Work done by 4 men in 1 day = 205 = 4 units

Work done by 1 man in 1 day = 2020 = 1 units

Since, 4 men worked for 1 day, they finished 4 units of work.

Remaining work = 20 – 4 = 16 units

This work will be done by 1 man in 16 days.

Question 22
In a certain coding scheme:'India is a growing economic power in world' is written as 'ba,fa,ga,si,na,wa, ta,mo''Population of India is growing' is written as 'ja,ka.ba,si,ga''Culture of India is soft power' is written as 'sa,ka,si,ba, la,wa'What are the codes for 'power' and 'of'?
  • A.wa,ka
  • B.wa,ba
  • C.ka,ba
  • D.wa,si
Correct Answer: wa,ka

From the first sentence we see that 'power' is represented by 'wa'.

From the second sentence we see that 'of' is represented by 'ka'.

Question 23
Find the missing term in the following letter series:AMZ, BLY, CNX, DKW, EOV…….. ?
  • A.FPU
  • B.FJU
  • C.FQX
  • D.FRU
Correct Answer: FJU

The first letter is advancing alphabetically: A, B, C, D, E

The second letter is advancing alphabetically, but in reverse order: M, L, N, K, O

The third letter is advancing alphabetically: Z, Y, X, W, V

So, next term will be FJU.

Question 24
Time taken by a motorboat moving downstream in a river to cover a distance and time taken by the motorboat to cover the same distance upstream are in the ratio of 3:5. If the speed of stream is 10 km/hr, what is the speed of boat?
  • A.20 km/hr
  • B.25 km/hr
  • C.30 km/hr
  • D.40 km/hr
Correct Answer: 40 km/hr

Let d be the distance covered. x be the speed of the boat and y be the speed pf stream

Then, dx+ydx-y = 35

or x = 4y

Speed of boat = 4 × 10 = 40 km/hr

Question 25
A Person sells an item at a discount of 40% and still makes a profit of 20%. By what percentage was the marked price of the item more than the cost price of the item?
  • A.50%
  • B.100%
  • C.150%
  • D.120%.
Correct Answer: 100%

Let MP = x

Then, SP = 0.6x

CP = 0.6x×100120 = 0.5x

Required percentage = x-0.5x0.5x × 100 = 100%

Question 26
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):A fallacy is a defect in an argument that consists of something other than merely false premises.Statement (II):If an argument is unsound oruncogent, it has one or more false premises, or it contains a fallacy or both.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.

Both Statements are correct.

Question 27
Which of the following is arranged in order of decreasing connotation?
  • A.Instrument, musical instrument, string instrument, violin
  • B.Violin, musical instrument, string instrument, instrument
  • C.Violin, string instrument, musical instrument, instrument
  • D.Instrument, string instrument, musical instrument, violin
Correct Answer: Violin, string instrument, musical instrument, instrument

Option C is correct

Begins with the most specific term "violin."

Followed by "string instrument," which is a broader category encompassing violins and other stringed instruments.

Next is "musical instrument," which is a broader category encompassing all types of musical instruments.

Ends with the broadest category "instrument," which includes all types of instruments, not limited to musical ones.

Question 28
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):A valid deductive argument cannot have all true premises and a false conclusion.Statement (II):The concept of truth cannot be applied to arguments.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.

Both Statements are correct.

Question 29
‘If you love hot cakes and you love ice creams, then you will surely love hot cake ice cream’. Which fallacy is committed in the above argument?
  • A.Fallacy of composition
  • B.Slippery slope
  • C.Fallacy of division
  • D.Hasty generalization
Correct Answer: Fallacy of composition

The fallacy of composition assumes that what is true for the individual parts must also be true for the whole. In this case, the argument says that because you love both hot cakes and ice cream separately, you will automatically love hot cake ice cream (the combination). However, just because you enjoy the individual components doesn't guarantee you'll like the combined flavor or texture.

Question 30
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Nyayasyllogism has 3 propositions and 5 terms.Statement (II):Aristotelian syllogism has 3 propositions and 3 terms.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true.

Nyaya Syllogism has 5 Propositions and 3 terms. Hence Statement I is false.

Question 31
Consider the base - 10 number 100. In base - 6, it would be represented as
  • A.(442)6
  • B.(200)6
  • C.(242)6
  • D.2446
Correct Answer: 2446

1006 = 16 and Remainder 4

166 = 2 and Remainder 4

26 = 0 and Remainder 2

Thus, (100)10 = (244)6

Question 32
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Wiki is usually in some form of chronological order and postings tend to be short in length.Statement II:A mobile phone (cell phone) primarily uses flash memory.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.

Wiki refers to a type of website that allows collaborative editing of its content by users. While some wikis may organize content in chronological order (e.g., for historical events), many wikis organize content based on topics, categories, or other methods. Additionally, the length of postings on a wiki can vary widely, from short entries to lengthy articles. Therefore, statement I is false.

 

Flash memory is commonly used in mobile phones (cell phones) for storing data such as operating system software, applications, photos, videos, and other user data. Flash memory is preferred for mobile devices due to its speed, durability, and energy efficiency compared to traditional hard disk drives. Therefore, statement II is true.

Question 33
Given below are two statements:Statement I:RFID is the use of fingerprint scans, retina scans, face identification, etc. as a way of identifying a person uniquely.Statement II:The website using the streaming method to deliver video means that the video can be played while it is being downloaded and accordingly less time is required before users can view the video.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.

RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification) is a technology that uses radio waves to identify and track tags attached to objects or people. It does not involve fingerprint scans, retina scans, or face identification, which are biometric identification methods. Therefore, statement I is false.

 

Streaming video allows users to start watching a video before the entire file has been downloaded. The video is delivered in a continuous stream of data, allowing playback to begin almost immediately and reducing the waiting time for users. Therefore, statement II is true.

Question 34
Which of the following statements are true?A. One of the main advantages of ROM is that the information stored on the ROM chip is not lost even when the power to the computer is turned off.B. ASCII is an acronym for American Standard Code for Intelligent Information.C. Compared to desktop computers, laptop computers are portable since all its components are together in one single unit.
  • A.A and B only
  • B.A and C only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A, B and C
Correct Answer: A and C only

ROM stands for Read-Only Memory. It is a type of computer memory that stores data and instructions that are permanently written during the manufacturing process. Unlike RAM (Random Access Memory), which is volatile and loses its data when the power is turned off, ROM retains its contents even when the power is turned off. So A is correct.

ASCII stands for American Standard Code for Information Interchange, not "Intelligent Information." It is a character encoding standard that is used to represent text in computers and other devices that use text. So B is incorrect.

Compared to desktop computers, laptop computers are portable because all their components are integrated into one single unit, making them easier to carry and use in different locations. So C is correct.

Question 35
Match List IwithList IIList I (Use)A. To select options from a list.B. To type data into a database.C. To input candidate's MCQ answer marked in pre-determined positions.D. To input data directly from a bank card.List II (Appropriate Input Device)I. KeyboardII. OMRIII. Chip ReaderIV. Mouse
  • A.A-II, B - III, C-I, D - IV
  • B.A-III, B - I, C -II, D - IV
  • C.A-IV, B -I, C -II, D - III
  • D.A- IV, B - II, C - I, D - III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B -I, C -II, D - III

A keyboard is an input device that allows a user to input text, numbers, and commands into a computer or other devices by pressing keys. So the correct match from the list I will be to type data into a database.

 

OMR is a technology used to detect marks made by a pen or pencil on a printed form. It is often used in surveys, tests, and questionnaires where respondents mark their answers by filling in bubbles or checkboxes. The marks are then read by an OMR scanner, which interprets the responses. So the correct match from the list I will be to input candidate's MCQ answer marked in pre-determined positions.

 

A chip reader, also known as a smart card reader, is a device used to read data from smart cards or integrated circuit cards. These cards contain a chip that stores information and can be used for authentication, identification, and payment purposes. So the correct match from the list I will be to input data directly from a bank card

 

A mouse is an input device that is used to control the movement of a cursor on a computer screen. It typically has one or more buttons that can be clicked to select items or perform actions. The mouse is moved by sliding it across a flat surface, and its movement is translated into corresponding movements of the cursor on the screen. So the correct match from the list I will be to select options from a list.

Question 36
In which one of the following Conference of Parties (COP) Kyoto protocol was adopted?
  • A.COP - 1
  • B.COP - 3
  • C.COP - 7
  • D.COP - 10
Correct Answer: COP - 3

The Kyoto Protocol was adopted at the third Conference of the Parties (COP 3) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) held in Kyoto, Japan, in December 1997.

Question 37
If a water body is healthy and supports no significant biological activity, then its condition is called as
  • A.Hypotrophic
  • B.Mesotrophic
  • C.Eutrophic
  • D.Oligotrophic
Correct Answer: Oligotrophic

Oligotrophic is a body of water such as a lake or pond, that has low levels of nutrients, such as nitrogen and phosphorus. In oligotrophic environments, the nutrient concentrations are relatively low, resulting in limited plant growth and productivity. These water bodies have clear water with high oxygen levels and support a relatively small population of organisms compared to eutrophic (nutrient-rich) environments.

Question 38
To qualify as hazardous waste, a waste must have the following characteristics:A. IgnitabilityB.CorrosivityC. ReactivityD. ToxicityE. RadioactivityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C and D only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A, B, C and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D and E

For any waste to be characterized as a hazardous waste, it should have the following characteristics:

 

1) Ignitability: The waste's propensity to catch fire. Examples include solvents (e.g., acetone, methanol), gasoline, oil-based paints, and some industrial chemicals (e.g., diethyl ether).

 

2) Corrosivity: The waste's ability to corrode containers or equipment. Examples include strong acids (e.g., sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid), strong bases (e.g., sodium hydroxide), and battery acid.

 

3) Reactivity: The waste's instability and potential to react violently with other substances. Examples include sodium, potassium, and some laboratory reagents.

 

4) Toxicity: The waste's capacity to harm human health or the environment when released.

 

A waste that has a hazardous component and a radioactive component is called a mixed waste. It is important to note that all hazardous wastes are not radioactive but all radioactive waste are hazardous in nature.

Question 39
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Acid rain occurs within, and downwind of areas of major industrial emissions of sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen.Statement II:Long range transport of airborne pollutants can be responsible for acid rain in areas far off from industrial emissions.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true, but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false, but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Acid rain is formed when sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) are released into the atmosphere from industrial activities, such as burning fossil fuels in power plants and vehicles. These pollutants react with water vapor, oxygen, and other chemicals in the atmosphere to form sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and nitric acid (HNO3), which can fall to the ground as acid rain.

While acid rain is often associated with local industrial emissions, pollutants can be carried long distances by winds and atmospheric currents before being deposited as acid rain in areas far from the original emission sources. This phenomenon, known as long-range transport, can result in acid rain affecting regions that are not directly downwind of major industrial areas. Therefore, both statements are true.

Question 40
'Life below water' pertains to which of the SDGs?
  • A.SDG 13
  • B.SDG 14
  • C.SDG 15
  • D.SDG 12
Correct Answer: SDG 14

SDG 14 focuses on "Life Below Water" and aims to conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas, and marine resources for sustainable development. The goal has ten targets that address various aspects of marine conservation, sustainable fisheries, marine pollution, and ocean acidification.

Question 41
Ujjain, in ancient India, was famous for the study of
  • A.Veterinary science
  • B.Chinese philosophy
  • C.Astronomy
  • D.Community work
Correct Answer: Astronomy

Option C is correct.

Ujjain, an ancient city in India, was historically renowned for its contributions to astronomy. It was a significant center for astronomical studies during ancient times, particularly during the period of classical Indian astronomy.

Several important astronomical observatories were located in Ujjain, including the one established by the renowned astronomer and mathematician Aryabhata. Aryabhata's works had a profound impact on the development of Indian astronomy, and his observations and calculations significantly advanced the understanding of celestial phenomena.

Question 42
The National Knowledge Commission recommended 'needs-blind admissions' for
  • A.National universities
  • B.State universities
  • C.Private universities
  • D.Foreign universities operating in India
Correct Answer: State universities

Option B is correct.

Option B is correct.

The concept of "needs-blind admissions" refers to an admissions policy where the financial situation or ability to pay of an applicant is not taken into consideration during the admission process. Instead, admissions are based solely on the academic merits and qualifications of the applicants.

One of the key recommendations made by the National Knowledge Commission was the implementation of needs-blind admissions, particularly in state universities. This recommendation aimed to ensure that deserving students, regardless of their financial background, have equal access to higher education opportunities.

Question 43
The Education/Despatchof 1854 suggested professional training inA. Library scienceB. LawC. MedicineD. Civil EngineeringE. Material scienceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, B and E only
Correct Answer: A, B and E only

Option D is correct.

Question 44
A policy framework developed by the UGC in 1978 suggested:A. Closure of private universities.B. Increase in the number of universities.C. Support for high quality experimental research.D. Discontinuation of autonomous colleges.E. Introduction of inter-disciplinary courses at undergraduate level.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.B, C and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and E only

Option D is correct.

A policy framework developed by the UGC in 1978 suggested the following

Increase in the number of universities with the goal was to improve access to higher education and accommodate the increasing demand for university education.

Support for high-quality experimental research with the objective of the UGC in promoting research and innovation within the higher education sector. Encouraging research activities contributes to the advancement of knowledge and academic excellence.

Introduction of interdisciplinary courses at the undergraduate level was a significant with the aim to provide students with a broader and more holistic education by integrating knowledge from multiple disciplines.

Question 45
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):According to the National Education Policy 2020, teaching duties will be more, and student-teacher ratio will be high, and faculty will be generally transferable across institutions in the country.Statement (II):According to the NEP, 2020, faculty will be given the liberty to design their pedagogical approaches for innovative teaching and research.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true
Correct Answer: Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.

Option C is correct.

Statement I is true. According to the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020, teaching duties will be increased, student-teacher ratio will be high, and faculty will be generally transferable across institutions in the country. The policy emphasizes the enhancement of teaching duties, aiming for a higher student-teacher ratio to ensure quality education delivery. Additionally, the NEP 2020 promotes faculty mobility and transferability across institutions to facilitate knowledge exchange and collaboration.

Statement II is false. According to the NEP 2020, faculty will be given the liberty to design their pedagogical approaches for innovative teaching and research. While the NEP 2020 does emphasize autonomy and flexibility for faculty in designing pedagogical approaches and conducting research, the specific aspect mentioned in Statement (II) regarding the liberty to design pedagogical approaches is not explicitly mentioned in the policy.

Question 46
Read the below passage and answer the following questions:Climate change and its imperatives across the globe have moved beyond the immediate compulsions of rising mercury levels on planet Earth. It is today a debate among nations on geo-politics and the shift in economic balance from the developed countries to the emerging economies. The rhetoric by global leaders thus needs to be taken with a pinch of salt for it is not all about climate change concerns. The changing axis of economic power to the East and emerging countries of Asia will perhaps take a while to sink in. Developing economies like India are just beginning to take baby steps on the global stage and industry and entrepreneurship will have to go a long way. Millions of households in India still have to depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes even as scores of Indians die every year for want of basic health amenities. The priority for such a nation is meeting basic needs, providing food, health, and education rather than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. India needs to do its bit, but on its own terms and at its own pace.The main focus of the passage in on:
  • A.Climate change and its impact
  • B.Climate change and geopolitics
  • C.Climate change and developmental imperatives
  • D.Climate change and mitigation strategies
Correct Answer: Climate change and geopolitics

The passage discusses how climate change has become a topic of debate among nations, not just due to its environmental impact but also because of its implications for geopolitics and the global economic balance. It highlights the shift in economic power from developed countries to emerging economies like India and the need for these countries to prioritize their developmental imperatives while addressing climate change concerns. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

Question 47
Read the below passage and answer the following questions:Climate change and its imperatives across the globe have moved beyond the immediate compulsions of rising mercury levels on planet Earth. It is today a debate among nations on geo-politics and the shift in economic balance from the developed countries to the emerging economies. The rhetoric by global leaders thus needs to be taken with a pinch of salt for it is not all about climate change concerns. The changing axis of economic power to the East and emerging countries of Asia will perhaps take a while to sink in. Developing economies like India are just beginning to take baby steps on the global stage and industry and entrepreneurship will have to go a long way. Millions of households in India still have to depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes even as scores of Indians die every year for want of basic health amenities. The priority for such a nation is meeting basic needs, providing food, health, and education rather than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. India needs to do its bit, but on its own terms and at its own pace.What are the problems faced by developing economies like India?A. They are extremely poor.B. Many people in India lack basic health amenities.C. They are extremely rich.D. Millions of people still depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.B and D only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and D only

The problems faced by developing economies like India, as mentioned in the passage, are:

 

(i) Many people in India lack basic health amenities.

(ii) Millions of people still depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 48
Read the below passage and answer the following questions:Climate change and its imperatives across the globe have moved beyond the immediate compulsions of rising mercury levels on planet Earth. It is today a debate among nations on geo-politics and the shift in economic balance from the developed countries to the emerging economies. The rhetoric by global leaders thus needs to be taken with a pinch of salt for it is not all about climate change concerns. The changing axis of economic power to the East and emerging countries of Asia will perhaps take a while to sink in. Developing economies like India are just beginning to take baby steps on the global stage and industry and entrepreneurship will have to go a long way. Millions of households in India still have to depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes even as scores of Indians die every year for want of basic health amenities. The priority for such a nation is meeting basic needs, providing food, health, and education rather than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. India needs to do its bit, but on its own terms and at its own pace.What should India first and foremost focus on?
  • A.Developing indigenous technologies to cut emissions
  • B.Importing technologies to cut emissions
  • C.Provide food. health and education to its people
  • D.Spend large sums of money to cut down emissions
Correct Answer: Provide food. health and education to its people

The passage emphasizes that for developing economies like India, the priority should be meeting basic needs such as food, health, and education for its people. This is highlighted as more crucial than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. Therefore, option C is correct.

Question 49
Read the below passage and answer the following questions:Climate change and its imperatives across the globe have moved beyond the immediate compulsions of rising mercury levels on planet Earth. It is today a debate among nations on geo-politics and the shift in economic balance from the developed countries to the emerging economies. The rhetoric by global leaders thus needs to be taken with a pinch of salt for it is not all about climate change concerns. The changing axis of economic power to the East and emerging countries of Asia will perhaps take a while to sink in. Developing economies like India are just beginning to take baby steps on the global stage and industry and entrepreneurship will have to go a long way. Millions of households in India still have to depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes even as scores of Indians die every year for want of basic health amenities. The priority for such a nation is meeting basic needs, providing food, health, and education rather than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. India needs to do its bit, but on its own terms and at its own pace.Which of the following facts related to climate change are true?A. The global leaders are indifferent to the issue of climate change.B. The climate change talks are sometimes directed towards political and economic gain rather than climate change.C. It is about the shift in economic balance from the developed economies to the emerging economies.D. Developing economies like India can afford to spend large sums of money to cut emissions.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.B, C and D only
  • D.A and D only
Correct Answer: B and C only

The true facts related to climate change, as stated in the passage, are:

 

(i) The climate change talks are sometimes directed towards political and economic gain rather than climate change.

(ii) It is about the shift in economic balance from the developed economies to the emerging economies.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 50
Read the below passage and answer the following questions:Climate change and its imperatives across the globe have moved beyond the immediate compulsions of rising mercury levels on planet Earth. It is today a debate among nations on geo-politics and the shift in economic balance from the developed countries to the emerging economies. The rhetoric by global leaders thus needs to be taken with a pinch of salt for it is not all about climate change concerns. The changing axis of economic power to the East and emerging countries of Asia will perhaps take a while to sink in. Developing economies like India are just beginning to take baby steps on the global stage and industry and entrepreneurship will have to go a long way. Millions of households in India still have to depend on firewood and kerosene to light up their homes even as scores of Indians die every year for want of basic health amenities. The priority for such a nation is meeting basic needs, providing food, health, and education rather than spending large portions of its GDP on importing technologies to cut emissions. India needs to do its bit, but on its own terms and at its own pace.Given below are two statements:Statement (I):India should take measures to cut down emissions but not at the cost of development.Statement (II):India should ban the use of firewood and kerosene and opt for cleaner fuels.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false, but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.

Statement (I) is true, but Statement (II) is false.

 

Statement (I) reflects the idea presented in the passage that India needs to address emissions but prioritize meeting basic developmental needs. This aligns with the passage's emphasis on focusing on basic necessities rather than solely on emission reduction technologies.

 

Statement (II), however, suggests a specific course of action (banning firewood and kerosene) which is not explicitly mentioned in the passage. Therefore, it cannot be considered true based on the given information.

Quiz Attempt #119735

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Table-1 below shows the state-wise foreign investments (inRs. crore) in the year 2022 and Table-2 shows the percentage (%) distribution of investments in different sectors for each state.Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow.Table 1: State-wise Details of Foreign InvestmentStateForeign Investment (inRs. Crore)Rajasthan3120Madhya Pradesh (MP)3560Gujarat3940Tamil Nadu (TN)1380Andhra Pradesh (AP)1460Delhi1660Haryana3880Table 2: Sector-wise Distribution of investment for each statePercentage (%) Distribution of Investment for each state inDefenceTelecomInsurancePharmaceuticalsConstructionOthers25.6%13.5%18.5%8.5%14.4%19.5%What is the total foreign investment (inRs. crore) in 'Others' sector in all the seven states together?
  • A.3297
  • B.3505
  • C.3705
  • D.3905
Correct Answer: 3705

Total investment in all the seven states = 19000 crore

Total investment in Others sector = 19.5% of 19000 = 3705 crore.

Question 2

Crore)Rajasthan3120Madhya Pradesh (MP)3560Gujarat3940Tamil Nadu (TN)1380Andhra Pradesh (AP)1460Delhi1660Haryana3880Table 2: Sector-wise Distribution of investment for each statePercentage (%) Distribution of Investment for each state inDefenceTelecomInsurancePharmaceuticalsConstructionOthers25.6%13.5%18.5%8.5%14.4%19.5%The foreign investment in Insurance sector in Rajasthan is approximately ________% of the foreign investment in Construction sector in Haryana.

Question 5
Table-1 below shows the state-wise foreign investments (inRs. crore) in the year 2022 and Table-2 shows the percentage (%) distribution of investments in different sectors for each state.Based on the data in the tables, answer the questions that follow.Table 1: State-wise Details of Foreign InvestmentStateForeign Investment (inRs. Crore)Rajasthan3120Madhya Pradesh (MP)3560Gujarat3940Tamil Nadu (TN)1380Andhra Pradesh (AP)1460Delhi1660Haryana3880Table 2: Sector-wise Distribution of investment for each statePercentage (%) Distribution of Investment for each state inDefenceTelecomInsurancePharmaceuticalsConstructionOthers25.6%13.5%18.5%8.5%14.4%19.5%What is the difference (inRs. crore) between the foreign investment inDefencesector in Gujarat andin Construction and Insurance sectors together in MP?
  • A.142.8
  • B.184.4
  • C.176.2
  • D.162.6
Correct Answer: 162.6

Defence sector in Gujarat = 25.6% of 3940 = 1008.64

in Construction and Insurance sectors together in MP = 32.9% of 3560 = 1171.24

Difference = 162.6

Question 6
Which of the following is not a benefit of Mind Mapping?
  • A.Improving memory retention
  • B.Enhancing creativity and problem solving skills
  • C.Reducing stress and anxiety
  • D.Making information more difficult to comprehend
Correct Answer: Making information more difficult to comprehend

Mind mapping is an effective means to take notes and brainstorm essay topics. A mind map involves writing down a central theme and thinking of new and related ideas which radiate out from the centre.

 

‘Making information more difficult to comprehend’, this statement is contrary to the purpose of mind mapping. Mind mapping is designed to simplify and clarify information by organizing it visually in a way that highlights connections and relationships between ideas. It is meant to enhance understanding and comprehension, not hinder it. Therefore, this option is not a benefit of mind mapping.

 

Mind mapping involves visualizing information in a structured and interconnected way, which can aid in memory retention. When you create a mind map, you're organizing information spatially, which can make it easier to recall later on.

 

Mind mapping encourages brainstorming and association of ideas, which can stimulate creativity and help in problem-solving by exploring different connections and perspectives.

 

Mind mapping can serve as a tool for organizing thoughts and tasks, which can help reduce feelings of overwhelm and stress. By breaking down complex ideas or tasks into manageable chunks, individuals may feel more in control and less anxious.

Question 7
Which of the following are not the characteristics of Adolescent learners?A. They have uniformity in their physical development.B. They have stable self-concepts.C. They often experience mood swings and emotional turmoil.D. They have high hopes and aspirations for their future.E. They have increased peer group pressure.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D and E only
  • B.C and D only
  • C.B, C and E only
  • D.A and B only
Correct Answer: A and B only

Let us consider each given characteristic one by one with respect to Adolescent learners.

 

A. They have uniformity in their physical development: This statement is incorrect. Adolescent learners typically undergo rapid and varied physical development during puberty, with individuals experiencing growth spurts and changes at different rates.

 

B. They have stable self-concepts: This statement is also incorrect. Adolescence is a time of significant identity formation, and self-concepts can be fluid and evolving as individuals explore different aspects of themselves and their identities.

 

C. They often experience mood swings and emotional turmoil: This is a characteristic commonly associated with adolescent learners. Hormonal changes and the challenges of transitioning from childhood to adulthood can lead to mood swings and emotional ups and downs.

 

D. They have high hopes and aspirations for their future: This is generally true for many adolescent learners. They often have high hopes and aspirations for their future careers, relationships, and personal development.

 

E. They have increased peer group pressure: This is another common characteristic of adolescent learners. Peer influence and pressure can be significant during this stage of life as individuals seek acceptance and validation from their peers.

 

So, options A and B are not characteristics of adolescent learners, making option (D) the correct answer.

Question 8
Which of the following are the National coordinators for the production of best quality content in SWAYAM?(a) NCTE(b) AICTE(c) IGNOU(d) UGC(e) CECChoose The correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (d) and (e) only
  • B.(b), (c) (d) and (e) only
  • C.(a) and (c) only
  • D.(a) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (b), (c) (d) and (e) only

National Coordinators are the Institutions that have been so designated by the Ministry and assigned a specific sector or preparation of online courses for SWAYAM.

 

The list of 9 National Coordinators is:

 

1. ICTE (All India Council for Technical Education) for self-paced and international courses

2. NPTEL (National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning) for Engineering

3. UGC (University Grants Commission) for non technical post-graduation education

4. CEC (Consortium for Educational Communication) for under-graduate education

5. NCERT (National Council of Educational Research and Training) for school education

6. NIOS (National Institute of Open Schooling) for school education

7. IGNOU (Indira Gandhi National Open University) for out-of-school students

8. IIMB (Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore) for management studies

9. NITTTR (National Institute of Technical Teachers Training and Research) for Teacher Training programme.

 

Hence, correct answer is option B.

Question 9
Which of the following is not the objective of teaching?
  • A.To help students to become better thinkers
  • B.To facilitate the development of problem-solving ability among students.
  • C.To follow a rigid teaching plan
  • D.To help learner, adjust his perceptions to reality, attaining harmony between internal and external experiences
Correct Answer: To follow a rigid teaching plan

The statement ‘to follow a rigid teaching plan’ contradicts the idea of effective teaching, which often involves flexibility and responsiveness to student needs and learning styles. While having a plan is important, being rigid can hinder adaptation to students' evolving needs.

Therefore, correct answer is option C.

Question 10
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Edpuzzleis a tool used for mind mapping in education.Statement (II):Mindmeisteris a tool used for creating interactive videos in education.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.

EdPuzzle is a free assessment-centered tool that allows teachers and students to create interactive online videos by embedding either open-ended or multiple-choice questions, audio notes, audio tracks, or comments on a video.

 

MindMeister is an online mind mapping application that allows its users to visualize, share and present their thoughts via the cloud.

 

Therefore, Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.

Question 11
Identify the characteristics of open-ended questions in survey research:A. The questions suggest certain kinds of answers to the respondents.B. They are useful for exploring new areas.C. They are time consuming for interviewers to administer.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and C only
  • D.A, B and C
Correct Answer: B and C only

The characteristics of open-ended questions in survey research are:

(i) They are useful for exploring new areas.

(ii) They are time-consuming for interviewers to administer.

 

The statement "The questions suggest certain kinds of answers to the respondents" describes a characteristic of closed-ended questions rather than open-ended questions. Open-ended questions allow respondents to provide their own answers without being constrained by predefined response options.

 

Open-ended questions are useful for exploring new areas because they allow respondents to express their thoughts, opinions, and experiences in their own words, providing researchers with rich qualitative data.

 

Open-ended questions can be time-consuming for interviewers to administer because they require respondents to provide detailed responses, which may take longer to process compared to closed-ended questions with predefined response options.

 

Thus, Option B is correct.

Question 12
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):In a reference written in APA style, the first name of an author is written first.Statement (II):In a reference written in APA style, the year of the publication is written after the page number.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false but Statement (II) is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.

Option B is correct.

Statement I is false. In APA style, the author's last name is written first followed by their initials.

Statement II is also false. In APA style, the year of publication typically comes immediately after the author(s) and before other publication information such as the title and source.

Question 13
Match List-IwithList-II:List-I (Types of Research I study)(a) Basic Research(b) Correlational Research(c) Case study(d) Longitudinal studyList-II (Description)(i) Investigations meant to discover whether variablescovary(ii) Anindepthstudy of a single or a few individuals to see how changes affect the person'sbehaviour(iii) A group of participants is observed and measured overtimee(iv) A study/research that tests or expands on theorychoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)

Option B is correct.

Basic Research is a study/research that tests or expands on theory.

Correlational Research investigations meant to discover whether variables covary.

Case study is an in-depth study of a single or a few individuals to see how changes affect the person's behavior.

Longitudinal study involves a group of participants is observed and measured over time.

Question 14
Which among the following types of variables can NOT be rank ordered?
  • A.nominal
  • B.ordinal
  • C.interval
  • D.ratio
Correct Answer: nominal

Nominal variables: These variables represent categories with no inherent order or ranking. Examples include gender, ethnicity, or marital status. Since there is no meaningful order to these categories, they cannot be rank ordered.

 

Ordinal variables: These variables have categories with a defined order or ranking, but the intervals between the categories are not necessarily equal. Examples include educational attainment (e.g., high school diploma, bachelor's degree, master's degree) or socioeconomic status (e.g., low-income, middle-income, high-income).

 

Interval variables: These variables have categories with a defined order, and the intervals between categories are equal. Examples include temperature measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit scales. While these variables can be rank ordered, they also have meaningful intervals between the values.

 

Ratio variables: These variables have all the properties of interval variables, but they also have a true zero point, meaning that zero represents the absence of the measured quantity. Examples include height, weight, or income. Like interval variables, ratio variables can be rank ordered.

 

So, the variable that cannot be rank ordered is the nominal variable.

Question 15
According to UGC regulations 2018 on plagiarism, level 3 plagiarism refers to similarities
  • A.above 60%
  • B.below 10%
  • C.above 10% to 30%
  • D.above 40% to 60%
Correct Answer: above 60%

The University Grants Commission introduced regulations for the prevention of plagiarism, discussing the “Promotion of Academic Integrity”, as well as “Prevention of Plagiarism in Higher Educational Institutions (HEI)” regulations for 2018.

 

The main motive of UGC behind these regulations is to create awareness regarding the conduct of research, thesis, and dissertation along with the prevention of any kind of misconduct which primarily includes plagiarism.

 

According to these regulations, following are the levels of plagiarism.

 

LevelsDescription

Level 0Up to 10% similarity- No penalty

Level 1Above 10% to 40 % similarity

Level 2Above 40% to 60 % similarity

Level 3Above 60% similarity

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 16
According to the Hindu tradition, the purpose of good communication is to
  • A.create social groups
  • B.produce tasteful entertainment
  • C.make people seek enlightenment
  • D.offer an insight into materialism
Correct Answer: make people seek enlightenment

In Hindu philosophy, communication is often seen as a means to convey knowledge, wisdom, and spiritual truths. The ultimate goal of communication, therefore, is to facilitate the enlightenment or spiritual awakening of individuals, helping them gain deeper insights into the nature of reality, the self, and the divine.

Question 17
The maximum amount of information sent over a channel within a specific period of time reflects?
  • A.Communication process
  • B.Information overload
  • C.Transmission barriers
  • D.Channel capacity
Correct Answer: Channel capacity

Channel capacity refers to the maximum rate of information transfer or the maximum amount of information that a communication channel can handle within a given period of time. It is a measure of the efficiency and effectiveness of a communication channel in transmitting information. Therefore, option D, "Channel capacity" is the correct answer.

 

The communication process refers to the steps or stages involved in transmitting information from a sender to a receiver. These stages typically include encoding (the sender formulates a message), transmission (the message is sent through a chosen channel), reception (the receiver perceives the message), decoding (the receiver interprets the message), and feedback (the receiver responds to the message).

 

Information overload occurs when individuals are exposed to more information than they can effectively process or manage. It can lead to decreased decision-making quality, increased stress, and reduced productivity.

 

Transmission barriers refer to obstacles or factors that impede the effective transmission of messages between a sender and a receiver. These barriers can include physical noise (such as background noise or poor signal quality), semantic barriers (such as language differences or ambiguous messages), psychological barriers (such as preconceived notions or emotional states), and cultural barriers (such as differences in cultural norms or values).

Question 18
Which of the following are true in the case ofmetacommunication?A. It is intentional.B. It is not always intentional.C. It often takes place spontaneouslyD. It can modify itself.E. Itdecontextualisesitself.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

Jurgen Ruesch and Gregory Bateson introduced the term metacommunication, defined as “communication about communication,” in their 1951 book Communication: The Social Matrix of Psychiatry.

 

The term ‘metacognition’ refers to an individual’s awareness of his or her own mental processes. In other words, Metacommunication refers to communication about communication, where individuals convey information about the way a message is being communicated rather than the content of the message itself. Here's how each given option in the question applies:

 

A. It is intentional: This statement is not universally true. While metacommunication can indeed be intentional, it can also occur unintentionally, especially in nonverbal cues or subtle shifts in tone or body language that reveal underlying feelings or attitudes.

B. It is not always intentional: This statement is correct. As mentioned above, metacommunication can occur both intentionally and unintentionally.

C. It often takes place spontaneously: This statement is true. Metacommunication can occur spontaneously in response to the dynamics of a conversation or interaction, such as when someone adjusts their tone of voice to convey empathy or clarifies a misunderstanding.

D. It can modify itself: This statement is true. Metacommunication can involve feedback and adjustments to the communication process itself, such as clarifying ambiguous statements or providing additional context to enhance understanding.

E. It decontextualizes itself: This statement does not accurately describe metacommunication. Instead, metacommunication operates within the context of the ongoing communication exchange, providing additional information or insight into the way messages are being conveyed.

Question 19
Given below are two statements:Statement I:In the modern day world, language is an effective instrument of communication.Statement II:The Buddhists regard language as an important social practice.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false but Statement (II) is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.

Statement I: "In the modern-day world, language is an effective instrument of communication."

This statement is true. Language plays a crucial role in communication in modern society, facilitating the exchange of ideas, information, and culture among individuals and groups.

 

Statement II: "The Buddhists regard language as an important social practice."

This statement is also true. In Buddhist philosophy, language is often considered significant not only for communication but also as a means of expressing and preserving teachings, fostering understanding, and connecting individuals within the community.

 

Therefore, Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.

Question 20
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Communication media are neither neutral nor value free containers that carry information to different places.Statement II:No Communication technology has its own unique set of physical, technical, symbolic and environmental characteristics.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.

Statement I is true.

Communication media are neither neutral nor value-free containers that carry information to different places. This statement emphasizes that communication media are not neutral platforms but rather carry inherent biases, values, and perspectives. It highlights the idea that media can shape and influence the information they convey. This statement is true.

Statement II is false.

Each communication technology does have its own unique set of characteristics, including physical attributes (such as size, shape, and form), technical specifications (such as bandwidth, transmission speed, and range), symbolic meanings (such as cultural associations and connotations), and environmental impacts (such as energy consumption and waste generation).

Therefore, Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.

Question 21
Two persons X and Y can do a piece of work in n days. If X alone can complete the work in (n+3) days and Y alone can do the work in (n+12) days. find the value of n.
  • A.6
  • B.10
  • C.7
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 6

Let total work be n (n + 3) (n + 12).

X can do n (n + 3) (n + 12).(n+3) = n(n + 12) units per day

Y can do n (n + 3) (n + 12).(n+12) = n(n + 3) units per day

X + Y can do n (n + 3) (n + 12).n (n + 3) (n + 12) units per day

Now, n(n + 12) + n(n + 3) = (n + 3) (n + 12)

Solving the equation, we get

n = 6

Question 22
A man, while pointing towards a lady, said, "Her husband is the only son of my mother" How is the man related to the lady?
  • A.Husband
  • B.Son
  • C.Father-in-law
  • D.Brother-in-law
Correct Answer: Husband

"Her husband is the only son of my mother."This means that the man's mother has only one son, and that son is the lady's husband. Therefore, the man is the lady's husband.

Question 23
A girl walks straight in the opposite direction of the front door of her house. The front door of the house is facing towards south. After walking for 50 meters, the girl turns to her left and walks 100 meters, thereafter the girl turns right and stops after walking for 100 meters. Which direction the girl is facing now?
  • A.North
  • B.South
  • C.North-west
  • D.North-east
Correct Answer: North

She walks straight in the opposite direction of the front door, which means she walks towards the north. After walking 50 meters, she turns left. Since she was initially facing south, turning left from north would mean she's now facing west. She walks 100 meters to the west. Then, she turns right. If she's facing west and turns right, she would be facing north. So, after her movements, the girl is facing North.

Question 24
What number would replace question mark (?) in the series given below?1, 6, 18, 44, 98, 208, 430, ?
  • A.638
  • B.876
  • C.896
  • D.999
Correct Answer: 876

6 – 1 = 5

18 – 6 = 12 = 5 × 2 + 2

44 – 18 = 26 = 12 × 2 + 2

98 – 44 = 54 = 26 × 2 + 2

208 – 98 = 110 = 54 × 2 + 2

430 – 208 = 222 = 110 × 2 + 2

Next difference = 222 × 2 + 2 = 446

Next term = 430 + 446

= 876

Question 25
In a certain coding language:a) 'AMAN' is coded as 29b) 'RAMAN' is coded as 47How 'SHAM' will be coded in that language?
  • A.43
  • B.28
  • C.41
  • D.37
Correct Answer: 41

AMAN = 1 + 13 + 1 + 14 = 29

RAMAN = 18 + 1 + 13 + 1 + 14 = 47

SHAM = 19 + 8 + 1 + 13 = 41

Question 26
Which of the following statements are so related that if one of them is false, the other must be true, even though both of them can be true?A. Some cars are e-vehicles.B. Some cars are not e-vehiclesC. No cars are e-vehicles.D. All cars are e-vehicles.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.B and C only
  • C.A and C only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: A and B only

If one of them is false, the other must be true, even though both of them can be true, then Propositions are set to be sub-contrary.

Question 27
If the statement "All trucks are polluting vehicles" is given as true, which of the following statements could be immediately inferred to be false?A. Some trucks are polluting vehicles.B. Some polluting vehicles are trucks.C. Some trucks are not polluting vehicles.D. No trucks are polluting vehicles.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C and D only
  • B.A and B only
  • C.B and C only
  • D.A and C only
Correct Answer: C and D only

If Proposition A is given to be true, then Proposition E and Proposition O are false.

Question 28
Which of the following statements is equivalent to the statement - "Some non-realists are not non-philosophers."?
  • A.Somephilosophers are not realists
  • B.No philosophers are realists
  • C.Some realists are philosophers
  • D.Some philosophers are realists
Correct Answer: Somephilosophers are not realists

Given Statement is contra-position of option A.

Question 29
"No one has been ever able to prove that Glaciers in the arctic region are melting because of Global warming. Therefore, glaciers in the arctic region must be melting on their own." Which fallacy is committed in the above statement?
  • A.Fallacy of Accident
  • B.Slippery Slope
  • C.HastyGeneralisation
  • D.Appeal to Ignorance
Correct Answer: Appeal to Ignorance

Fallacy of Weak Induction happens when there is low probability of conclusion. Here Analogy is too weak to support a Conclusion (weak Induction, low probability).

The argument assumes that because something hasn't been proven (glaciers melting due to global warming), the opposite must be true (glaciers melting on their own). This is an example of the appeal to ignorance fallacy.

Question 30
According to classical Indian school of logic which of the following are names of fallacies involving contradiction of the middle term by another middle term?
  • A.Satpratipaksa
  • B.Ba-dhita
  • C.Vya-pyatva-siddha
  • D.Viruddha
Correct Answer: Satpratipaksa

Satpratipaksa : Here the middle term is contradicted by another middle term. The reason is counter-balanced by another reason. And both are of equal force; e.g., ‘sound is eternal, because it is audible and ‘sound is non-eternal, because it is produced. Here ‘audible is counter-balanced by ‘produced’ and both are of equal force.

Question 31
A Media Access Control (MAC) address refers to a number which uniquely identifies a device on the Internet and is usually made up of ________bits.
  • A.16
  • B.32
  • C.48
  • D.128
Correct Answer: 48

MAC Addresses are unique 48-bit hardware numbers of a computer that are embedded into a network card (known as a Network Interface Card) during manufacturing. The MAC Address is also known as the Physical Address of a network device.

Question 32
Which VLOOKUP in MS-EXCEL when entered into cell L2 and then dragged to cell L5, returns the average number of calls for representative IDs listed incoloumnJ?ABCJKL1Representative ID NumberAvg. Call Length (Mins.)Avg. Number of CallsRepresentative ID NumberHire DateAvg. Number of calls2411869.3139.2443899/29/193418886.1132.4418889/24/194424347.5129.5428866/10/155428868.3136.04118611/17/196430274.9126.97443897.0108.8
  • A.=VLOOKUP (A2, J2:L5, 1, FALSE)
  • B.=VLOOKUP (J2, A$2:C$7, 1, FALSE)
  • C.=VLOOKUP (J2, A$2:C$7, 3, FALSE)
  • D.=VLOOKUP (J2, A2:C7, 3, FALSE)
Correct Answer: =VLOOKUP (J2, A$2:C$7, 3, FALSE)

The correct answer is =VLOOKUP (J2, A$2:C$7, 3, FALSE)

Question 33
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack is the large number of requests sent at the same time to the web server, thereby causing the server to crash.Statement II:Virus is a self-replicating malicious software causing computer to run slowly.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack is an attempt to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users by flooding it with excessive requests. This flood of requests overwhelms the target server or network, causing it to become unresponsive or crash. Therefore, statement I is true.

A computer virus is a type of malicious software that, when executed, replicates by inserting copies of itself into other computer programs, data files, or the boot sector of the hard drive. Viruses can cause various harmful effects on a computer system, including slowing down its performance. Therefore, statement II is true.

Question 34
Which of the following statements about quantum computing are correct?a. Principles of quantum physics are applied in it.b. Quantum bits (qubits) are used as the information unit.c. Quantum Computers emit radiation fatal to humans/users.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(a) and (c) only
  • C.(b) and (c) only
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a) and (b) only

Quantum computing is a rapidly evolving field of computing that uses principles of quantum mechanics to process information in fundamentally new ways. Unlike classical computers, which use bits as the smallest unit of information (0 or 1), quantum computers use quantum bits, or qubits, which can represent and store information in both 0 and 1 simultaneously, thanks to a property called superposition.

Superposition allows quantum computers to perform many calculations simultaneously, potentially making them much faster than classical computers for certain tasks. Another quantum mechanical property called entanglement allows qubits to be correlated with each other, even when separated by large distances. This property can be harnessed to perform complex computations and solve problems that are currently intractable for classical computers.

Statement c is incorrect as quantum computers donot emit fatal radiation.

Question 35
Which of the following facilities are available in word-processing software such as MS-WORD?a. Find and Replaceb. Mail Mergec. Spell check and thesaurusd. Automatic RecalculationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(b) and (c) only
  • C.(c) and (d) only
  • D.(a), (b) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c) only

The correct answer is option A i.e., (a), (b) and (c) only.

 

a. Find and Replace: This feature allows users to search for specific words or phrases within a document and replace them with alternative words or phrases. It helps in editing and formatting large documents efficiently.

 

b. Mail Merge: Mail merge is a feature that enables users to create personalized documents, such as letters or envelopes, by merging a template document with a data source, such as a spreadsheet or database. It is commonly used for generating mass mailings with customized content.

 

c. Spell check and thesaurus: Word-processing software typically includes spell check functionality to identify and correct spelling errors in documents. Additionally, a thesaurus feature is often included to help users find synonyms and expand their vocabulary while writing.

 

d. Automatic Recalculation: This feature is more commonly associated with spreadsheet software like Microsoft Excel rather than word-processing software like MS Word. Automatic recalculation automatically updates calculations and formulas in spreadsheets when input values change. It is not a standard feature in word-processing software.

Question 36
When a water body is deficient in nutrients, it is known as:
  • A.Oligotrophic
  • B.Eutrophic
  • C.Mesotrophic
  • D.Dystrophic
Correct Answer: Oligotrophic

Oligotrophic describes a water body that is low in nutrients, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus. Oligotrophic waters are clear, deep, and have low levels of algae and aquatic plants. These environments often have clean, oxygen-rich water and support a limited number of fish species compared to more nutrient-rich waters. Oligotrophic conditions can occur naturally in certain lakes and ponds, or they can result from human activities that reduce nutrient inputs into water bodies.

 

Dystrophic waters are characterized by high levels of dissolved organic matter, which gives them a dark tea-like color. This organic matter is often derived from decaying vegetation in surrounding wetlands or forests. Dystrophic waters are low in nutrients and can be acidic due to the breakdown of organic material. These waters may support unique ecosystems adapted to low-nutrient conditions and acidic environments.

 

Oligotrophic describes a water body that is low in nutrients, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus, leading to clear water with low levels of algae and aquatic plants. Dystrophic, on the other hand, describes water that is darkly colored due to high levels of dissolved organic matter, also typically low in nutrients. Both conditions represent different aspects of nutrient deficiency in water bodies.

Question 37
Discovery of Ozone hole was first made over
  • A.Arctic
  • B.Equator
  • C.Antarctic
  • D.Tropics
Correct Answer: Antarctic

The discovery of the ozone hole was first made over Antarctica in the mid-1980s. Scientists observed a significant thinning of the ozone layer in the stratosphere over Antarctica during the spring season, leading to the formation of a "hole" in the ozone layer.

Question 38
What is the correct increasing order of prescribed limits for following pollutants on 24 hours basis in residential areas by CPCB?a. Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM)b.RespirableSuspended Particulate Matter (RSPM)c. Lead (pb)d. Ammonia (NH3)Choose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b, c, d
  • B.b, a, c, d
  • C.c, d, b, a
  • D.c, b, a, d
Correct Answer: c, b, a, d

The prescribed limits for the following pollutants on a 24-hour basis in residential areas by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) are as follows:

 

1. Lead (Pb): Lead is regulated by the CPCB, and its prescribed limit (1.0 µg/m3) for residential areas is typically lower than other pollutants.

 

2. Respirable Suspended Particulate Matter (RSPM): RSPM refers to fine particles suspended in the air that can penetrate deep into the respiratory system. The CPCB has prescribed limits for RSPM (60 µg/m3) in residential areas to protect public health.

 

3. Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM): SPM includes both fine and coarse particles suspended in the air. The CPCB has prescribed limits for SPM (100 µg/m3)in residential areas to protect air quality and public health.

 

4. Ammonia (NH3): Ammonia is a gaseous pollutant, and the CPCB has prescribed limits for NH3 (400 µg/m3)in residential areas to protect air quality and public health.

Question 39
Given below are two statements:Statement I:A nuclear power reactor is a system designed to sustain a fission chain reaction and extract useful energy.Statement II:Light water reactors use ordinary water as the moderator.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

Nuclear power reactors are designed to control and sustain a controlled chain reaction of nuclear fission, where the nucleus of an atom splits into smaller parts, releasing energy. This energy is then used to generate electricity. Therefore, statement I is true.

Light water reactors (LWRs) use ordinary water, specifically light water (H2O), as both the coolant and the moderator. The water slows down the neutrons produced in the fission process, allowing them to more effectively cause further fissions in the nuclear fuel, sustaining the chain reaction. Therefore, statement II is true.

Question 40
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Composting is aerobic degradation of organic materials under controlled conditions, yielding a marketable manure.Statement II:In such composts, concentrations of key nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium are sufficient enough to compete with commercial fertilizers.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false.

Composting is a process that involves the decomposition of organic materials, such as food scraps, yard waste, and manure, by microorganisms under controlled aerobic conditions. The end product of composting is a nutrient-rich soil amendment known as compost, which can be used as a fertilizer or soil conditioner. Therefore, statement I is true.

While compost is a valuable source of nutrients for plants, its nutrient content may vary depending on the materials used in the composting process. Compost typically contains lower concentrations of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium compared to commercial fertilizers. However, compost provides other benefits, such as improving soil structure, enhancing water retention, and promoting beneficial soil microorganisms, making it a valuable addition to soil health and fertility management. Therefore, statement II is false.

Question 41
Who among the following opposed the implementation of western system of education in India?
  • A.William Adam
  • B.Lord Canning
  • C.Mrs. Annie Besant
  • D.B.L. Rice
Correct Answer: Mrs. Annie Besant

Option C is correct.

Mrs. Annie Besant was a prominent British socialist, theosophist, women's rights activist, and supporter of Indian self-rule. She was also deeply involved in the education system in India. Besant advocated for a more indigenous and culturally relevant education system rather than the Western system that was being imposed during British colonial rule.

During her time in India, Annie Besant established several educational institutions, including the Central Hindu College in Varanasi (now known as the Banaras Hindu University) and the Madanapalle College in Andhra Pradesh. These institutions aimed to combine Indian and Western education systems, emphasizing the preservation of Indian culture and heritage while also providing modern education.

Question 42
The Indian university Act, 1904, was passed during the period of ________ as viceroy.
  • A.Lord Wellesley
  • B.Lord Ripon
  • C.Lord Curzon
  • D.Lord Chelmsford
Correct Answer: Lord Curzon

The Indian University Act of 1904 was enacted during the viceroyalty of Lord Curzon. This act aimed to reform the higher education system in India by introducing regulations for universities and standardizing academic standards and practices across institutions.

Question 43
Which of the following autonomous scientific institutions come under the financial umbrella of the Department of Science and Technology?a. Bose Institute, Kolkatab.AgarkarResearch Institute, Punec. RamanResearch Institute, Bangalore.d.WadiaInstitute of Himalayan Geology, Dehradune. Indian Council of Astrological science, BangaloreChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and e only
  • B.b, d and e only
  • C.c, d and e only
  • D.a, b, c and d only
Correct Answer: a, b, c and d only

Option D is correct.

Bose Institute, Kolkata; Agarkar Research Institute, Pune; Raman Research Institute, Bangalore and Wadia Institute of Himalayan Geology, Dehradun are autonomous scientific institutions that come under the financial umbrella of the Department of Science and Technology (DST). These institutions receive financial support and guidance from DST for their scientific research activities.

Indian Council of Astrological Sciences, is not a scientific institution recognized by the Department of Science and Technology. Astrology is not considered a science by mainstream scientific communities, and thus, it does not fall under the purview of scientific institutions funded by the DST.

Question 44
Who among the following are said to have had their education atTakshashilla?a. SriChaitanyab. Paninic.Nagarjunad.ChanakyaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (c) only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) only
  • C.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • D.(b) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (b) and (d) only

Option D is correct.

Takshashila (also known as Taxila) was an ancient city located in present-day Pakistan. It was a renowned center of learning and education in ancient India. Among the options provided:

Panini, the ancient Sanskrit grammarian, is believed to have studied at Takshashila. His work, the Ashtadhyayi, is one of the earliest known grammatical treatises in the world.

Chanakya, also known as Kautilya or Vishnugupta, is believed to have studied and taught at Takshashila. He is famous for being the author of the Arthashastra and for being the mentor and advisor of Chandragupta Maurya, the founder of the Maurya Empire.

Question 45
In 1902, in a telegram to Hamilton, who among the following proposed to appointIndian Universitiescommission with six permanent members?
  • A.S.H. Wood
  • B.A. Abbott
  • C.Lord Curzon
  • D.Lord Macaulay
Correct Answer: Lord Curzon

The proposal to appoint the Indian Universities Commission with six permanent members in a telegram to Hamilton in 1902 was made by Lord Curzon.

Question 46
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Based on molecular evidence, we know life evolved from one common ancestor around three billion years ago. From then, evolution progressed, slowly to begin with - in the last billion years, we see very rapid diversification of life forms on Earth as multiple components clicked into place, includingmulticellularityor multiple cells coming together to form one organism etc. Against this backdrop, we find all insects share a relationship with each other - they have a certain body plan, cellular functions, genetically encoded features (many have six legs, for instance) and the information of how these features are formed encoded in their genome. Butterflies share many evolutionary features with insects. Butterflies are alsospecialisedmoths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago. Thereafter, moths themselves evolved significantly before butterflies emerged as a separate group about 85 million years ago, around when dinosaurs went extinct. All the characteristics butterflies have-including much more acute vision compared to moths who rely more on smell - grew thereon. Visual cues are extremely important for butterflies which explains why many are so attractive. Their appealingcoloursevolved to help them either evade predators or attract mates, darkcoloursdeveloping to help butterflies maintain body temperature, being cold-blooded.Some species developed fascinating traits.Aposematismis a combination of two features - one is adefenceagainst predators, like a chemical cover, some butterflies being toxic to birds, spiders, etc. These caterpillars feed on toxic plants which are difficult, if not deadly, for predators to digest. Being protected thus is an internal property - but butterflies with toxins then developed bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous, signaling the risk they bear.Butterflies and Insects separated:
  • A.1 million years ago
  • B.85 million years ago
  • C.150-200 million years ago
  • D.3 billion years ago
Correct Answer: 150-200 million years ago

The passage mentions that butterflies and moths separated from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago.

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Based on molecular evidence, we know life evolved from one common ancestor around three billion years ago.
