From then, evolution progressed, slowly to begin with - in the last billion years, we see very rapid diversification of life forms on Earth as multiple components clicked into place, includingmulticellularityor multiple cells coming together to form one organism etc. Against this backdrop, we find all insects share a relationship with each other - they have a certain body plan, cellular functions, genetically encoded features (many have six legs, for instance) and the information of how these features are formed encoded in their genome. Butterflies share many evolutionary features with insects. Butterflies are alsospecialisedmoths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago. Thereafter, moths themselves evolved significantly before butterflies emerged as a separate group about 85 million years ago, around when dinosaurs went extinct. All the characteristics butterflies have-including much more acute vision compared to moths who rely more on smell - grew thereon. Visual cues are extremely important for butterflies which explains why many are so attractive. Their appealingcoloursevolved to help them either evade predators or attract mates, darkcoloursdeveloping to help butterflies maintain body temperature, being cold-blooded.Some species developed fascinating traits.Aposematismis a combination of two features - one is adefenceagainst predators, like a chemical cover, some butterflies being toxic to birds, spiders, etc. These caterpillars feed on toxic plants which are difficult, if not deadly, for predators to digest. Being protected thus is an internal property - but butterflies with toxins then developed bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous, signaling the risk they bear.Compared to moths, butterfliesa. have better visionb. rely more on smelling powerc. are less attractived. are more colorfulChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (c) only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) only
  • C.(a) and (d) only
  • D.(a), (c) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (a) and (d) only

The correct answer is option C, i.e., (a) and (d) only. Lets consider each option one by one.

 

a. Butterflies have better vision: The passage states that butterflies have much more acute vision compared to moths, which rely more on smell. Therefore, option (a) is correct.

b. Butterflies rely more on smelling power: This statement contradicts the information provided in the passage. The passage explicitly states that moths rely more on smell, while butterflies have better vision.

c. Butterflies are less attractive: This statement is not supported by the passage. In fact, the passage explains that visual cues are extremely important for butterflies, and their appealing colors evolved to help them evade predators or attract mates.

d. Butterflies are more colorful: This statement is supported by the passage, which mentions that butterflies have appealing colors that evolved to serve various purposes such as evading predators or attracting mates.

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Based on molecular evidence, we know life evolved from one common ancestor around three billion years ago. From then, evolution progressed, slowly to begin with - in the last billion years, we see very rapid diversification of life forms on Earth as multiple components clicked into place, includingmulticellularityor multiple cells coming together to form one organism etc. Against this backdrop, we find all insects share a relationship with each other - they have a certain body plan, cellular functions, genetically encoded features (many have six legs, for instance) and the information of how these features are formed encoded in their genome. Butterflies share many evolutionary features with insects. Butterflies are alsospecialisedmoths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago. Thereafter, moths themselves evolved significantly before butterflies emerged as a separate group about 85 million years ago, around when dinosaurs went extinct. All the characteristics butterflies have-including much more acute vision compared to moths who rely more on smell - grew thereon. Visual cues are extremely important for butterflies which explains why many are so attractive. Their appealingcoloursevolved to help them either evade predators or attract mates, darkcoloursdeveloping to help butterflies maintain body temperature, being cold-blooded.Some species developed fascinating traits.Aposematismis a combination of two features - one is adefenceagainst predators, like a chemical cover, some butterflies being toxic to birds, spiders, etc. These caterpillars feed on toxic plants which are difficult, if not deadly, for predators to digest. Being protected thus is an internal property - but butterflies with toxins then developed bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous, signaling the risk they bear.Appealingcoloursof butterflies serve all these purposes:a. Repel matesb. Evade predatorsc. Maintain body temperatured. Attract predators.e. Attract matesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(a), (b), (c) and (d) only
  • C.(b), (c), (d) and (e)
  • D.(b), (c) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (b), (c) and (e) only

The correct answer is option (D) i.e., (b), (c) and (e) only.

 

(i) Evade predators: The passage states that appealing colors of butterflies evolved to help them evade predators. Therefore, option (b) is correct.

 

(ii) Maintain body temperature: The passage explains that dark colors developed in butterflies to help them maintain body temperature as they are cold-blooded. Therefore, option (c) is correct.

 

(iii) Attract mates: The passage implies that appealing colors of butterflies evolved to attract mates. Therefore, option (e) is correct.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Based on molecular evidence, we know life evolved from one common ancestor around three billion years ago. From then, evolution progressed, slowly to begin with - in the last billion years, we see very rapid diversification of life forms on Earth as multiple components clicked into place, includingmulticellularityor multiple cells coming together to form one organism etc. Against this backdrop, we find all insects share a relationship with each other - they have a certain body plan, cellular functions, genetically encoded features (many have six legs, for instance) and the information of how these features are formed encoded in their genome. Butterflies share many evolutionary features with insects. Butterflies are alsospecialisedmoths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago. Thereafter, moths themselves evolved significantly before butterflies emerged as a separate group about 85 million years ago, around when dinosaurs went extinct. All the characteristics butterflies have-including much more acute vision compared to moths who rely more on smell - grew thereon. Visual cues are extremely important for butterflies which explains why many are so attractive. Their appealingcoloursevolved to help them either evade predators or attract mates, darkcoloursdeveloping to help butterflies maintain body temperature, being cold-blooded.Some species developed fascinating traits.Aposematismis a combination of two features - one is adefenceagainst predators, like a chemical cover, some butterflies being toxic to birds, spiders, etc. These caterpillars feed on toxic plants which are difficult, if not deadly, for predators to digest. Being protected thus is an internal property - but butterflies with toxins then developed bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous, signaling the risk they bear.Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Butterflies are specialized moths.Statement (II):Butterflies emerged as a separate group about the time when dinosaurs went extinct.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.
  • B.Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are false.
  • C.Statement (I) is true but Statement (II) is false.
  • D.Statement (I) is false but Statement (II) is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are true.

Statement (I): "Butterflies are specialized moths." This statement is true, as stated in the passage, ‘Butterflies are also specialised moths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago.’

 

Statement (II): "Butterflies emerged as a separate group about the time when dinosaurs went extinct." This statement is also true according to the passage. It mentions that butterflies emerged as a separate group around 85 million years ago, which approximately coincides with the extinction of dinosaurs.

 

Therefore, option A is correct.

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Based on molecular evidence, we know life evolved from one common ancestor around three billion years ago. From then, evolution progressed, slowly to begin with - in the last billion years, we see very rapid diversification of life forms on Earth as multiple components clicked into place, includingmulticellularityor multiple cells coming together to form one organism etc. Against this backdrop, we find all insects share a relationship with each other - they have a certain body plan, cellular functions, genetically encoded features (many have six legs, for instance) and the information of how these features are formed encoded in their genome. Butterflies share many evolutionary features with insects. Butterflies are alsospecialisedmoths, the two separating from their sister group of insects 150 to 200 million years ago. Thereafter, moths themselves evolved significantly before butterflies emerged as a separate group about 85 million years ago, around when dinosaurs went extinct. All the characteristics butterflies have-including much more acute vision compared to moths who rely more on smell - grew thereon. Visual cues are extremely important for butterflies which explains why many are so attractive. Their appealingcoloursevolved to help them either evade predators or attract mates, darkcoloursdeveloping to help butterflies maintain body temperature, being cold-blooded.Some species developed fascinating traits.Aposematismis a combination of two features - one is adefenceagainst predators, like a chemical cover, some butterflies being toxic to birds, spiders, etc. These caterpillars feed on toxic plants which are difficult, if not deadly, for predators to digest. Being protected thus is an internal property - but butterflies with toxins then developed bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous, signaling the risk they bear.Aposematismis a combination ofa.Defenceagainst predators by emitting a bad Smell.b. Bright wing patterns for camouflage.c.Defenceagainst predators by butterflies with toxins.d. Bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (d) only
  • B.(b) and (c) only
  • C.(c) and (d) only
  • D.(d) only
Correct Answer: (c) and (d) only

The correct answer is option C, i.e., (c) and (d) only. Let us consider each option one by one.

 

a. Defence against predators by emitting a bad smell: This statement is not mentioned in the passage as a characteristic of aposematism. Therefore, option (a) is not correct.

b. Bright wing patterns for camouflage: This statement is not accurate. Aposematism involves the use of bright colors or patterns as a warning signal to predators, not for camouflage. Therefore, option (b) is not correct.

c. Defence against predators by butterflies with toxins: This statement is accurate. Aposematism involves the defense against predators by organisms that are toxic or harmful. Some butterflies feed on toxic plants and develop toxins that make them unpalatable to predators.

d. Bright wing patterns to show predators they are dangerous: This statement is also accurate. Aposematic organisms, including butterflies with toxins, often have bright and conspicuous color patterns that serve as warning signals to predators, indicating their potential danger.

Quiz Attempt #119736

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of six different types of expenditure, namely, Salary (S), Infrastructure (I), Transportation (T), Bonus (BO), Raw Material (R) and Miscellaneous (M) of three companies A, B and C during a given year. Total expenditure of company A, B and C areRs. 80 lakh,Rs. 90 lakh andRs. 75 lakh, respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Company-wise percentage (%) distribution of ExpenditureCompanyType of ExpenditureSITBORMA24%18%15%10%14%19%B27%15%14%25%9%10%C21%24%16%19%8%12%What is the difference between the expenditure of Company-Aon salary and the expenditure of Company-B on Raw Material?
  • A.Rs. 9.6 lakh
  • B.Rs. 11.1 lakh
  • C.Rs. 12.4 lakh
  • D.Rs. 13.4 lakh
Correct Answer: Rs. 11.1 lakh

Required difference = 24% of 80 – 9% of 90 = 19.2 – 8.1 = 11.1 lakh

Question 2
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of six different types of expenditure, namely, Salary (S), Infrastructure (I), Transportation (T), Bonus (BO), Raw Material (R) and Miscellaneous (M) of three companies A, B and C during a given year. Total expenditure of company A, B and C areRs. 80 lakh,Rs. 90 lakh andRs. 75 lakh, respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Company-wise percentage (%) distribution of ExpenditureCompanyType of ExpenditureSITBORMA24%18%15%10%14%19%B27%15%14%25%9%10%C21%24%16%19%8%12%The expenditure of Company C on salary is approximately _______ % of the expenditure of Company A on Transportation.
  • A.76.2%
  • B.96%
  • C.125%
  • D.131%
Correct Answer: 131%

Required percentage = 21% of 7515% of 80 × 100 ≈ 131%

Question 3
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of six different types of expenditure, namely, Salary (S), Infrastructure (I), Transportation (T), Bonus (BO), Raw Material (R) and Miscellaneous (M) of three companies A, B and C during a given year. Total expenditure of company A, B and C areRs. 80 lakh,Rs. 90 lakh andRs. 75 lakh, respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Company-wise percentage (%) distribution of ExpenditureCompanyType of ExpenditureSITBORMA24%18%15%10%14%19%B27%15%14%25%9%10%C21%24%16%19%8%12%What is the average expenditure of the three companies on Infrastructure?
  • A.Rs. 12.2 lakh
  • B.Rs. 15.3 lakh
  • C.Rs. 16.4 lakh
  • D.Rs. 17.5 lakh
Correct Answer: Rs. 15.3 lakh

Average expenditure = 18% of 80+15% of 90+24% of 753 = 15.3 lakh

Question 4
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of six different types of expenditure, namely, Salary (S), Infrastructure (I), Transportation (T), Bonus (BO), Raw Material (R) and Miscellaneous (M) of three companies A, B and C during a given year. Total expenditure of company A, B and C areRs. 80 lakh,Rs. 90 lakh andRs. 75 lakh, respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Company-wise percentage (%) distribution of ExpenditureCompanyType of ExpenditureSITBORMA24%18%15%10%14%19%B27%15%14%25%9%10%C21%24%16%19%8%12%What is the ratio of the expenditure of Company A on Infrastructure to the expenditure of Company B on Transportation?
  • A.5:4
  • B.6:5
  • C.7:6
  • D.8:7
Correct Answer: 8:7

Required ratio = 18% of 8014% of 90 = 8 : 7

Question 5
The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of six different types of expenditure, namely, Salary (S), Infrastructure (I), Transportation (T), Bonus (BO), Raw Material (R) and Miscellaneous (M) of three companies A, B and C during a given year. Total expenditure of company A, B and C areRs. 80 lakh,Rs. 90 lakh andRs. 75 lakh, respectively. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow:Company-wise percentage (%) distribution of ExpenditureCompanyType of ExpenditureSITBORMA24%18%15%10%14%19%B27%15%14%25%9%10%C21%24%16%19%8%12%The expenditure of Company C on Infrastructure is ___________% more or less than the expenditure of Company A on Bonus.
  • A.80
  • B.100
  • C.125
  • D.150
Correct Answer: 125

Required percentage = 24% of 75-10%of 8010% of 80 × 100 = 125%

Question 6
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Swayamprabhacourses are broadcasted on TV.Statement (II):Moocsare only available in English.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options givenbelow.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

"Swayamprabha courses are broadcasted on TV." This statement is correct. The SWAYAM-PRABHA is a group of 40 DTH channels devoted to telecasting of high-quality educational programmes on 24X7 basis using the GSAT-15 satellite.

 

"MOOCs are only available in English." This statement is incorrect. MOOCs, or Massive Open Online Courses, are available in various languages, not just English. Many platforms offer courses in multiple languages to cater to learners from different linguistic backgrounds.

Question 7
Match List - IwithList - II.List - I (Types of Evaluation)(a) Placement Evaluation(b) Formative Evaluation(c) Summative Evaluation(d) Diagnostic EvaluationList - II (Their Functions)(I) To monitor the learning progress of students during the course of instructions(II) To know the underlying cause of weaknesses in students' learning(III) To know entrybehaviour(IV) To certify the learner at the end of a course or an academic year or programmeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)

The correct match is as follows.

(a) Placement Evaluation: To know entry behavior

(b) Formative Evaluation: To monitor the learning progress of students during the course of instructions

(c) Summative Evaluation: To certify the learner at the end of a course or an academic year or programme

(d) Diagnostic Evaluation: To know the underlying cause of weaknesses in students' learning

Question 8
Research suggests that a majority of students cheat at some points in their academic career. Which one of the following is not a recommendation to reduce cheating in the classroom?
  • A.Encourage collaboration with peers on assignments to provide necessary support and decrease anxiety.
  • B.Reduce the focus on grades and provide the material for students with which they must be familiar.
  • C.Clear guidelines on what constitutes cheating accompanied by consequences that, when imposed, will deter other students due to their severity.
  • D.Ensure students are well prepared for assignments and tests
Correct Answer: Reduce the focus on grades and provide the material for students with which they must be familiar.

The recommendation that is not typically suggested to reduce cheating in the classroom is reduce the focus on grades and provide the material for students with which they must be familiar.

 

(i) Encouraging collaboration with peers on assignments can create a supportive environment and decrease anxiety, which may reduce the incentive to cheat.

(ii) Providing clear guidelines on what constitutes cheating and imposing consequences for cheating can deter students from engaging in dishonest behavior.

(iii) Ensuring that students are well-prepared for assignments and tests can reduce the temptation to cheat by minimizing feelings of inadequacy or pressure.

 

However, option B suggests reducing the focus on grades, which may not directly address the issue of cheating. While reducing grade pressure can be beneficial for student well-being, it may not necessarily deter cheating behavior.

Question 9
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Adolescents tend to be highly self-aware and have a clear sense of their identity.Statement (II):Adolescents tend to develop ability to see relationships and to solve problems of increasing complexity and difficulty.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Statement (I): "Adolescents tend to be highly self-aware and have a clear sense of their identity." This statement is generally not accurate. Adolescence is a period of significant self-discovery and identity formation, but it is also marked by uncertainty, exploration, and sometimes confusion regarding one's identity. Therefore, Statement I is incorrect.

Statement (II): "Adolescents tend to develop the ability to see relationships and to solve problems of increasing complexity and difficulty." This statement aligns with developmental psychology research, which suggests that cognitive abilities, such as abstract thinking, problem-solving, and understanding complex relationships, tend to improve during adolescence as the brain undergoes significant development. Therefore, Statement II is correct.

Question 10
Which of the following is a basic requirement for effective teaching?
  • A.Ignoring individual differences among students
  • B.Adequate resources and technology
  • C.Use of traditional teaching methods
  • D.Rigid adherence to curriculum guidelines
Correct Answer: Adequate resources and technology

Let us consider each option one by one.

 

Ignoring individual differences among students: Ignoring individual differences can hinder effective teaching as it fails to address the diverse needs and learning styles of students.

 

Adequate resources and technology: Having access to adequate resources and technology is crucial for effective teaching. Resources such as textbooks, teaching materials, and technology tools enhance the learning experience and enable teachers to create engaging and interactive lessons.

 

Use of traditional teaching methods: While traditional teaching methods can still be effective in certain contexts, effective teaching often involves a variety of instructional strategies tailored to meet the needs of diverse learners.

 

Rigid adherence to curriculum guidelines: While adherence to curriculum guidelines is important, rigid adherence may limit teachers' ability to adapt instruction to meet the unique needs of their students.

 

Therefore, the option that is a basic requirement for effective teaching is adequate resources and technology.

Question 11
If you want to understand the theoretical reasons that led researchers to conduct a study, you would read which section of their article?
  • A.Abstract
  • B.Introduction
  • C.Discussion
  • D.Methodology
Correct Answer: Introduction

The introduction section of a research article provides background information on the topic, presents the research problem or question, reviews relevant literature, and outlines the theoretical framework guiding the study. Therefore, the introduction is where researchers typically provide the theoretical rationale for their study.

Question 12
The tendency of researchers to subtly and inadvertently affect thebehavioursof participants in a study, obscuring the true effect of the independent variable, refers to :
  • A.Hawthorne Effect
  • B.Biosocial Effect
  • C.Experimental Bias
  • D.Participant Bias
Correct Answer: Experimental Bias

Option C is correct.

Experimental Bias refers to the actions or behaviors of researchers that unintentionally influence the outcomes of the study. This bias can manifest in various ways, such as through subtle cues, unintentional influence on participant behavior, or unconscious favoritism towards certain outcomes. It's a key consideration in designing and conducting experiments to ensure the validity and reliability of the results.

Question 13
A research design in which either the investigator or the participant is not aware of the treatment a participant is receiving, refers to :
  • A.Single Blind Study
  • B.Half Blind Study
  • C.Double Blind Study
  • D.Longitudinal Study
Correct Answer: Single Blind Study

Single blind study is a type of clinical trial in which only the researcher doing the study knows which treatment or intervention the participant is receiving until the trial is over. A single-blind study makes results of the study less likely to be biased. This means that the results are less likely to be affected by factors that are not related to the treatment or intervention being tested.

Question 14
In a positively skewed distribution, which among the following would betrue ?(a) Mean > Mode(b) Mode > Median(c) Mean > Median(d) Mode > Mean(e) Median > MeanChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(b) and (d) only
  • B.(a) and (c) only
  • C.(a) and (b) only
  • D.(d) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (a) and (c) only

In a positively skewed distribution, the mean is typically greater than the median and the mode because the few larger values on the higher end of the distribution pull the mean towards them.

Thus, only statements a and c are correct.

Question 15
A researcher computes sample correlationcoefficientsr1,r2,r3, andr4from four different samples and obtains 0.97, 0.95, 0.10 and 0.03, respectively, as their p-values. The correlation coefficient significant at 5% level is:
  • A.r1
  • B.r2
  • C.r3
  • D.r4
Correct Answer: r4

To determine which correlation coefficient is significant at the 5% level (typically a significance level of α = 0.05), we compare the p-values with this threshold. If the p-value is less than 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the correlation coefficient is statistically significant.

So, the correlation coefficient that is significant at the 5% level is r4 since its p-value (0.03) is less than 0.05.

Question 16
When individuals post journal-like entries on the Internet, they are known as:
  • A.Advisory Columns
  • B.Net Opinions
  • C.Weblogs
  • D.Digital Stories
Correct Answer: Weblogs

Weblogs, commonly referred to as "blogs," are online platforms where individuals post personal journal-like entries, commentaries, or reflections on various topics. Blogs often contain a series of entries arranged in reverse chronological order, allowing readers to engage with the content and often providing opportunities for interaction through comments or social media sharing.

Question 17
An implicit message within a message is technically referred to as :
  • A.Hidden Message
  • B.Intrinsic Message
  • C.Non-expressive Message
  • D.Sub-text
Correct Answer: Sub-text

Subtext refers to the underlying or implicit meaning conveyed in a message that may not be explicitly stated but can be inferred or interpreted by the audience. It often involves the deeper or hidden intentions, emotions, or implications behind the surface content of the message.

For example, Surface text: "Hey, would you like to come over and watch a movie tonight?"

Subtext: The surface text might suggest a simple invitation to watch a movie together. However, the subtext could imply a desire for intimacy or a romantic interest, especially if the individuals involved have a close relationship or romantic history.

Question 18
Which of the following constitutes the selectivity process in mass communication?(a) Selective suppression(b) Selective attention(c) Selective perception(d) Selective retention(e) Selective ignoranceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) only
  • C.(c), (d) and (e) only
  • D.(a), (d) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (b), (c) and (d) only

The correct answer is option B.

 

Selective attention refers to the tendency of individuals to focus on certain aspects of a message while ignoring others. This can be influenced by personal interests, motivations, or the salience of certain information.

 

Selective perception involves interpreting information in a way that is consistent with one's existing beliefs, attitudes, or expectations. People may filter incoming information to fit their preconceived notions or biases.

 

Selective retention refers to the process by which individuals remember and recall information that is personally meaningful or relevant to them, while forgetting less significant or less emotionally charged information.

 

These three processes—selective attention, selective perception, and selective retention—shape how individuals engage with and respond to mass communication messages, influencing which information they pay attention to, how they interpret it, and what they remember from it.

Question 19
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Under the framework of communication, politicalsocialisationis related to social learning in terms of how power is acquired.Statement (II):Marginalisationis the basis of politicalsocialisation.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Let us examine Statement I.

 

Political socialization is the learning process by which people develop an understanding of their political identities, opinions, and behavior. Through various agents of socialization, such as parents, peers, and schools, the lifelong experiences of political socialization play a key role in developing the traits of patriotism and good citizenship. In other words, political socialisation is the process by which the ethos and behaviour of a political system is communicated from one generation to another generation.

 

According to Robert Sigel. "Political socialisation is the gradual learning of the norms, attitudes and behaviour acceptable to an on-going political system.”

 

The acquisition of power within a political system is closely intertwined with political socialization and social learning. As individuals learn about the norms and structures of political systems, they also learn about power dynamics, including who holds power, how it is exercised, and how it can be attained. This knowledge shapes individuals' perceptions of power and influences their behaviors and attitudes towards political participation, activism, and civic engagement. Thus, statement I is correct.

 

Let us examine Statement II.

 

In the context of political socialization, marginalization refers to the social process by which certain groups or individuals are systematically excluded or disadvantaged within society. This exclusion can manifest in various forms, such as limited access to political participation, resources, opportunities, or decision-making processes. Marginalized groups may experience discrimination, inequality, and a lack of representation in political institutions and processes.

 

In the statement provided, "Marginalization is the basis of political socialisation," it suggests that the experiences of being marginalized contribute fundamentally to how individuals develop their political attitudes, values, and behaviors. However, while marginalization may influence political socialization for some individuals or groups, it is not the sole basis of the process. Political socialization involves a complex interplay of various socializing agents, including family, education, media, peers, and broader societal structures and norms. Therefore, statement II is incorrect.

Question 20
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Media audiences are increasingly active in their communication with each other.Statement (II):Media audiences are also active in communication with creators of mass communication contents.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Statement (I) correctly highlights the increasing activity of media audiences in their communication with each other. With the rise of social media and online platforms, audiences have become more engaged and interactive, sharing opinions, discussing content, and forming communities around shared interests.

Statement (II) is also correct in stating that media audiences are active in communication with creators of mass communication content. Through social media, feedback mechanisms, and other channels, audiences can directly engage with content creators, providing feedback, asking questions, and influencing future content production.

Question 21
What number would replace question mark (?) in the series givenbelow ?31, 37, 41, 43, 47, 53, ?, 61
  • A.58
  • B.57
  • C.59
  • D.56
Correct Answer: 59

The given series is of prime numbers. So, the next number will be 59.

Question 22
A milkman has a mixture of milk in which the ratio of milk and water is 7:4. He sells 55litresof this mixture and then adds up 20litresof pure water. Now the ratio of milk and water is 7:6. Find the new quantity of this mixture.
  • A.70litres
  • B.195litres
  • C.130litres
  • D.210litres
Correct Answer: 130litres

In 55 litre of mixture there is 35 litres of milk and 20 litres of water.

Now, 3520+a 76

Or a = 10

New quantity = 13 × 10 = 130 litres

Question 23
A sum of money at simple rate of interest becomesRs. 2016 in 4 years andRs. 2286 in 9 years. What is the principal amount?
  • A.Rs. 1800
  • B.Rs. 1700
  • C.Rs. 1900
  • D.Rs. 1850
Correct Answer: Rs. 1800

270 = P×R×5100

or PR = 5400

Now 2016 = P + P×R×4100

or 2016 = P + 54 × 4

or P = 1800

Question 24
A salesman travels from Delhi toAmbalaat 30 km/h and returns at 90 km/h. If the total time taken is 8 hours, find the total distance covered by him.
  • A.480 km
  • B.240 km
  • C.360 km
  • D.280 km
Correct Answer: 360 km

Let x be the distance between the Delhi to Ambala.

Then, x30 + x90 = 8

or x = 180

Total distance covered = 180 + 180 = 360 km

Question 25
In a certain coding language:(a) 'tee see pee' means 'drink fruit juice'(b) 'seekeelee' means 'juice is sweet'(c) 'leereemee' means 'he is intelligent'Which word in this language means 'sweet’?
  • A.‘pee’
  • B.‘kee’
  • C.‘lee’
  • D.‘mee
Correct Answer: ‘kee’

Code for ‘juice’ is ‘see’

Code for ‘is’ is ‘lee’

Thus, Code for ‘sweet’ will be ‘kee’.

Question 26
Name the fallacy committed in the following argument:"All Russians were revolutionists.All Anarchists were revolutionists.Therefore, all Anarchists were Russians."(a) Fallacy of four terms(b) Fallacy of illicit process(c) Fallacy of undistributed middle(d) Fallacy of exclusive premisesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(b) and (c) only
  • C.(c) only
  • D.(c) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (c) only

A syllogism is a formal way of structuring an argument with two premises and a conclusion. In a valid syllogism, the term that appears in both premises (the middle term) must be distributed in at least one of the premises.

 

Premise 1: All Russians (R) were revolutionists (Rev).

Premise 2: All Anarchists (A) were revolutionists (Rev).

Conclusion: Therefore, all Anarchists (A) were Russians (R).

 

Here's why (c) is the correct answer:

 

The middle term is "revolutionists" (Rev).

However, neither premise distributes "revolutionists."

Premise 1 only talks about Russians who are revolutionists, not all revolutionists.

Premise 2 only talks about Anarchists who are revolutionists, not all revolutionists.

Because the middle term isn't distributed in either premise, we can't logically conclude that all Anarchists must be Russian.

Question 27
In the light of concept of 'Terms' which of the following is incorrect?(a) The set of attributes shared by all and only those objects to which a general term refers is called intension.(b) Every general term has both anintensionaland extensional meaning.(c) The extension of a term determines its intension.(d) Terms may have different intension but have the same extension.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(b) and (d) only
  • B.(a) and (b) only
  • C.(b) only
  • D.(c) only
Correct Answer: (c) only

Statement C is incorrect. The extension of a term is actually determines by its intension.

Question 28
In a square of opposition of propositions which of the following is correct?
  • A.If A is given as false; O is undetermined
  • B.If E is given as false; I is false
  • C.If I is given as false; A is false
  • D.If O is given as false; E is true
Correct Answer: If I is given as false; A is false

Option C is correct answer.

Question 29
In the context ofAnumana(Inference), the presence of the middle term in the minor term is called:
  • A.Para-marsha
  • B.Vya-pti
  • C.Paksadharmata-
  • D.Paksa
Correct Answer: Paksadharmata-

The presence of the middle term in the minor term is called paksadharmatä. The invariable association of the middle term with the major term is called vyâpti. The knowledge of paksadharmata as qualified by vyâpti is called parämarsha or inference.

Question 30
Which of the following is incorrect in the light of Inductive Argument?(a) If the premises are true then the conclusion is probably true.(b) The conclusion follows probably from the premises.(c) It is unlikely for the premises to be true and the conclusion false.(d) It is impossible for all the premises to be true and the conclusion false.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(b) and (c) only
  • C.(c) and (d) only
  • D.(d) only
Correct Answer: (d) only

Statement D is incorrect. This is the feature of deductive argument and not inductive argument.

Question 31
Which of the following pair of acronyms and its expansion are incorrectly matched?
  • A.LAN-Local Area Network
  • B.MAN-Metropolitan Area Network
  • C.WAN-Wide Area Network
  • D.VPN-Virtual Personal Network
Correct Answer: VPN-Virtual Personal Network

VPN stands for Virtual Private Network. It is a technology that creates a secure and encrypted connection over the internet, allowing users to access resources, share data, and browse the web privately and securely.

Question 32
Statement (I):(499)10=(111110011)2Statement (II):(1011101)2(93)10In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

(1011101)2 = 1 × 20 + 0 × 21 + 1 × 22 + 1 × 23 + 1 × 24 + 0 × 25 + 1 × 26

= 1 + 0 + 4 + 8 + 16 + 0 + 64

= 93

 

(111110011)2 = 1 × 20 + 1 × 21 + 0 × 22 + 0 × 23 + 1 × 24 + 1 × 25 + 1 × 26 + 1 × 27 + 1 × 28

= 1 + 2 + 0 + 0 + 16 + 32 + 64 + 128 + 256

= 499

Thus, both the statements are correct.

Question 33
Statement I:3D Printers are primarily used in CAD.Statement II:OLEDs require some form of backlighting so that the screen can be lit up.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

3D printers are commonly used in conjunction with Computer-Aided Design (CAD) software to create physical objects based on digital models. CAD software is used to design the object, and the 3D printer then translates this digital design into a physical object. Therefore, statement I is correct.

Unlike traditional LCD screens, OLED (Organic Light Emitting Diode) displays do not require a backlight. Each pixel in an OLED display emits its own light, allowing for deeper blacks and more vibrant colors compared to LCD screens. This is one of the key advantages of OLED technology. Therefore, statement II is incorrect.

Question 34
Which of the following statements relevant to the trends in modem information technology is/are correct?(a) In traditional computing, data is represented in binary digits while in quantum computing, data is represented in quantum bits orqubits.(b) A wearable device capable of activity tracking that measures data such as the number of steps walked, and heart rate is an example ofWiMAX.(c) A collection of nodes capable of environmental sensing, local computation, and communication with its peers or with other high performance nodes is called a Geographic Information System (GIS).Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) only
  • B.(b) only
  • C.(a) and (c) only
  • D.(b) and (c) only
Correct Answer: (a) only

Traditional computing uses binary digits (0 and 1) to represent data, while quantum computing uses quantum bits or qubits, which can represent a 0, a 1, or both simultaneously due to quantum superposition and entanglement. Therefore, statement a is correct.

WiMAX (Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access) is a wireless communication standard, not a wearable device for activity tracking. A wearable device for activity tracking would be an example of a fitness tracker or smartwatch. Therefore, statement b is incorrect.

A Geographic Information System (GIS) is a system designed to capture, store, manipulate, analyze, manage, and present spatial or geographic data. It is not specifically related to a collection of nodes capable of environmental sensing, local computation, and communication. Therefore, statement c is incorrect.

Question 35
Match List - IwithList – II.List-I (Cyber Attack)(a) Spyware(b) Phishing(c)Ransomware(d) PharmingList-II (Description)(i) Sending an email to lure users to fake website to obtain their personal details(ii) Downloading of malicious code to redirect users to fake website to obtain their personal details(iii)Keyloggerused to record key presses and sending them to third party(iv) Holding hostage a user's data, often for a release feeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)

Spyware is malicious software that is designed to spy on a user's activities without their knowledge or consent. It can gather information such as browsing habits, keystrokes, and personal information, which is then sent to a third party. Therefore, the correct description will be keylogger used to record key presses and sending them to third party.

 

Phishing is a type of cyber attack in which attackers use deceptive emails, websites, or messages to trick individuals into providing sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details. The goal is to steal personal or financial information. Therefore, the correct description is sending an email to lure users to fake website to obtain their personal details.

 

Ransomware is a form of malware that encrypts a user's files or locks their computer, rendering it unusable. Attackers then demand a ransom, usually in the form of cryptocurrency, in exchange for decrypting the files or unlocking the computer. Therefore, the correct description will be holding hostage a user's data, often for a release fee.

 

Pharming is a cyber attack that redirects website traffic from legitimate websites to fraudulent websites without the user's knowledge. Attackers typically do this by compromising the DNS (Domain Name System) or by using malware to modify the host file on a user's computer. Therefore the correct description will be downloading of malicious code to redirect users to fake website to obtain their personal details.

Question 36
Which one of the following is an essential requirement for the formation of photochemical smog?
  • A.Watervapour
  • B.Sunlight
  • C.High temperature
  • D.Snow
Correct Answer: Sunlight

Sunlight is an essential requirement for the formation of photochemical smog. Photochemical smog is formed when pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) react in the presence of sunlight to form ozone (O3) and other harmful pollutants. Without sunlight, the photochemical reactions that lead to the formation of photochemical smog would not occur.

Question 37
Which of the following elements is fissile?
  • A.Thorium - 232
  • B.Plutonium - 239
  • C.Uranium - 237
  • D.Uranium - 238
Correct Answer: Plutonium - 239

Plutonium-239 (Pu-239) is an isotope of plutonium, a radioactive metallic element. Pu-239 is significant because it is a fissile isotope, meaning it can sustain a nuclear chain reaction. This property makes it valuable for use in nuclear weapons and nuclear reactors.

Question 38
Sick Building Syndrome (SBS) is caused due to:
  • A.Aging of the building
  • B.Contaminated indoor air
  • C.Contaminated water supply in the building
  • D.Presence of building in a landslide prone area
Correct Answer: Contaminated indoor air

Sick Building Syndrome (SBS) is when people in a building feel unwell without a clear reason. Symptoms can include headaches, dizziness, nausea, fatigue, and eye, nose, or throat irritation. SBS may be due to factors like poor indoor air quality, lack of ventilation, and contaminants from sources like mold or chemicals.

Question 39
What is the correct increasing order of Global Warming Potential (GWP) of following gases?(a) Nitrous Oxide(N2O)(b) Carbon dioxide(CO2)(c) Methane(CH4)(d)ChloroFluoroCarbon(CFC)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (c), (d)
  • B.(a), (c), (b), (d)
  • C.(b), (a), (c), (d)
  • D.(b), (c), (a), (d)
Correct Answer: (b), (c), (a), (d)

The correct increasing order of Global Warming Potential (GWP) for the given gases is:

a) Carbon dioxide (CO2) - GWP = 1

b) Methane (CH4) - GWP = 25

c) Nitrous Oxide (N2O) - GWP = 298

d) Chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) - GWP = varies depending on the specific CFC

 

Therefore, the correct order is:

CO2 < CH4 < N2O < CFC

Question 40
What is the limit of water availability for a region to be classified as water scarce region?
  • A.Less than 2500m3/person/year
  • B.Less than 2000m3/person/year
  • C.Less than 1500m3/ person/year
  • D.Less than 1000m3/ person/year
Correct Answer: Less than 1000m3/ person/year

Water scarcity occurs when the demand for water exceeds the available supply. It is experienced by a country or region when the availability of clean, natural water drops below 1000 m3 per person per year.

Question 41
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):According to NEP 2020, one of the verticals of Higher Education Commission of India (HECI), General Education Council (GEC) will be responsible for accreditation of Higher Education Institutions (HEIs).Statement (II):According to NEP 2020, through a suitable system of graded accreditation and graded autonomy, and in a phased manner over a period of 15 years, all HEIs in India will aim to become independent self-governing institutions.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Option D is correct.

Statement I is incorrect. In the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020, the responsibility for accreditation of Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) is not assigned to the General Education Council (GEC). Rather, the responsibility for accreditation is vested in an autonomous body called the National Accreditation Council (NAC).

Statement II is correct. The NEP 2020 indeed outlines a vision for all Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) in India to aim for becoming independent self-governing institutions over a period of 15 years. This is to be achieved through a system of graded accreditation and graded autonomy, allowing institutions to gradually attain greater levels of self-governance and autonomy based on their performance and compliance with specified criteria

Question 42
In the preamble of the Indian Constitution which of the following value is not stated?
  • A.Justice
  • B.Equality
  • C.Courage
  • D.Liberty
Correct Answer: Courage

The preamble of the Indian Constitution states the following core values:

(i) Justice

(ii) Equality

(iii) Liberty

Hence, the correct answer is option C.

Question 43
Government of India constituted a University Education Commission in November-1948 under the Chairmanship of ____________
  • A.Dr.Lakshmanaswamy
  • B.ShriMaulanaAbulKalamAzad
  • C.Dr.Radhakrishnan
  • D.Dr.YashPal
Correct Answer: Dr.Radhakrishnan

After independence, the first significant step taken by the Government of India in the field of education was the appointment of the University Education Commission in 1948 under the Chairmanship of Dr. Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan, a distinguished scholar and former vice-chancellor of Banaras Hindu University and who then became the second President of India.

 

The Inter-University Board of Education (IUBE) and Central Advisory Board of Education (CABE) recommended to the Government of India that a Commission on Education should be appointed to inquire into the problems and prospects of Indian University Education and to suggest improvements and extensions that might be considered desirable to suit the present and future requirements of the country. Therefore, the Commission was appointed in November 1948 under the chairmanship of Dr. Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan, and it submitted its report in August,1949 which is why this Commission is also known as ‘Radhakrishnan Commission’.

Question 44
Match List -1 with List - II.List -I (Educational Stages)(a)Samavartan(b)Vasu(c)Rudra(d) AdityaList - II (Description)(i) Those who completed 48 years course or study of four Vedas(ii) Those who completed 36 years course or study of any three Vedas(iii) Those who completed 24 years course or study of any two Vedas() A convocation ceremonyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

The correct match is as follows.

List -I (Educational Stages) - List - II (Description)

(a) Samavartan - A convocation ceremony

(b) Vasu - Those who completed 24 years course or study of any two Vedas

(c) Rudra - Those who completed 36 years course or study of any three Vedas

(d) Aditya - Those who completed 48 years course or study of four Vedas

 

In the Vedic era, the esteemed role of educator was held by individuals known as Gurus. These Gurus were not just scholars of immense knowledge but also exemplars of dedication, truth, and remarkable character. They held a revered position in society, akin to that of a deity. For them, wisdom was true wealth, and their lives were dedicated to the pursuit of truth. Operating their own Gurukuls or Institutes of Education, Gurus personally oversaw the education system. Within the Gurukul, Gurus treated their disciples as their own children, fostering a familial bond. Unlike modern times, there was no system of examinations; instead, students engaged in a competition of knowledge. The proficiency of students was determined by their mastery of Vedic texts. Students who completed the syllabus of 12 years, mastering at least one Veda, were titled Karnatak. Those who pursued 24 years and learned at least 2 Vedas were known as Vasu, while those who pursued 36 years and learned 3 Vedas were called Rudra. The highest honor, bestowed upon those who completed 48 years and mastered all four Vedas, was the title of Aditya. Additionally, individuals who delved into Ayurveda, yoga, and the science of health were known as Ashwinikumar or Vaidya. Scripture describes a total of 33 categories of teachers, including 8 Vasus, 11 Rudra, 12 Aditya, and 2 Ashwin. Even in modern times, these revered figures are worshipped as gods, their wisdom and teachings continuing to inspire reverence and admiration.

Question 45
Who among the following was the moving force behind the enactment of the Indian Universities Act in the beginning of 20th Century?
  • A.Lord Canning
  • B.Lord Curzon
  • C.Charles Wood
  • D.Lord Dalhousie
Correct Answer: Lord Curzon

The Indian University Act of 1904 was enacted during the viceroyalty of Lord Curzon. This act aimed to reform the higher education system in India by introducing regulations for universities and standardizing academic standards and practices across institutions.

Question 46
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Feminism is a meta-ideology that has been receiving attention in many areas of social sciences in recent decades. The starting point for introducing gender to International Relations is with respect to debate about basic inequalities between males and females and the consequences of such inequalities on World Politics. The noted works on global gender issues argue that compared with men, women constitute the disadvantaged group. They own about 1 per cent of the world's property and less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions while they account for 60 per cent of all working hours but receive only 10 per cent of all income. Their condition issodeplorable as the illiteracy rate is high among them; that is 60 percent of all illiterates are women and 80 per cent of all refugees are women. This gender discrimination is apparent universally.A gender-sensitive focus on the world politics seeks to bring such challenges into open. It points out the working of international political and economic systems that tend to produce an underprivileged position for women. Jacqui True pointed out that economic development policies of structural adjustment adopted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank and changes in the international division oflabourcontribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'. Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabourare examples of how development in international economy engages in exploitation of women. Different forms of gender inequalities and discrimination may be found in advanced industrial societies even after many decades of high rates of participation of women in workfares.Women face gender inequalities and discrimination in:
  • A.Developing Nations
  • B.Developed Nations
  • C.Globally
  • D.Highly Industrialized Societies
Correct Answer: Globally

Women face gender inequalities and discrimination globally.

The passage discusses how gender inequalities and discrimination are apparent universally, affecting women across various regions and nations. It highlights disparities in property ownership, leadership positions, income distribution, literacy rates, and refugee populations, emphasizing that these issues are not limited to specific countries or regions but are widespread globally.

Question 47
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Feminism is a meta-ideology that has been receiving attention in many areas of social sciences in recent decades. The starting point for introducing gender to International Relations is with respect to debate about basic inequalities between males and females and the consequences of such inequalities on World Politics. The noted works on global gender issues argue that compared with men, women constitute the disadvantaged group. They own about 1 per cent of the world's property and less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions while they account for 60 per cent of all working hours but receive only 10 per cent of all income. Their condition issodeplorable as the illiteracy rate is high among them; that is 60 percent of all illiterates are women and 80 per cent of all refugees are women. This gender discrimination is apparent universally.A gender-sensitive focus on the world politics seeks to bring such challenges into open. It points out the working of international political and economic systems that tend to produce an underprivileged position for women. Jacqui True pointed out that economic development policies of structural adjustment adopted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank and changes in the international division oflabourcontribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'. Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabourare examples of how development in international economy engages in exploitation of women. Different forms of gender inequalities and discrimination may be found in advanced industrial societies even after many decades of high rates of participation of women in workfares.Why do women constitute the disadvantaged group?(a) Own more property than man(b) Get lower wages than men(c) Work longer hours for less wages(d) Are less literate than men(e) Have limited positions of powerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(b) and (d) only
  • C.(b), (d) and (a) only
  • D.(b), (c), (d) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (b), (c), (d) and (e) only

Women constitute the disadvantaged group for multiple reasons as outlined in the passage:

(i) They receive lower wages than men.

(ii) They work longer hours for less wages.

(iii) The illiteracy rate is high among women.

(iv) They have limited positions of power, as indicated by the fact that less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions.

Question 48
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Feminism is a meta-ideology that has been receiving attention in many areas of social sciences in recent decades. The starting point for introducing gender to International Relations is with respect to debate about basic inequalities between males and females and the consequences of such inequalities on World Politics. The noted works on global gender issues argue that compared with men, women constitute the disadvantaged group. They own about 1 per cent of the world's property and less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions while they account for 60 per cent of all working hours but receive only 10 per cent of all income. Their condition issodeplorable as the illiteracy rate is high among them; that is 60 percent of all illiterates are women and 80 per cent of all refugees are women. This gender discrimination is apparent universally.A gender-sensitive focus on the world politics seeks to bring such challenges into open. It points out the working of international political and economic systems that tend to produce an underprivileged position for women. Jacqui True pointed out that economic development policies of structural adjustment adopted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank and changes in the international division oflabourcontribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'. Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabourare examples of how development in international economy engages in exploitation of women. Different forms of gender inequalities and discrimination may be found in advanced industrial societies even after many decades of high rates of participation of women in workfares.Choose the statements that are correct.(a) 20% of all refugees are men(b) Less than 5% women head higher organizations and position of power(c) 60% of all illiterates are women(d) Women account for 10% of all working hours(e) Men receive 90% of all incomeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(c), (d) and (e) only
  • C.(b) and (c) only
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c) and (e) only

From the passage:

(i) 80 percent of all refugees are women.

(ii) Less than 5 percent of women head higher organizations and positions of power.

(iii) 60 percent of all illiterates are women.

(iv) Women receive only 10 percent of all income.

Thus, options (a), (b), (c), and (e) correctly reflect the statements provided in the passage.

Question 49
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Feminism is a meta-ideology that has been receiving attention in many areas of social sciences in recent decades. The starting point for introducing gender to International Relations is with respect to debate about basic inequalities between males and females and the consequences of such inequalities on World Politics. The noted works on global gender issues argue that compared with men, women constitute the disadvantaged group. They own about 1 per cent of the world's property and less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions while they account for 60 per cent of all working hours but receive only 10 per cent of all income. Their condition issodeplorable as the illiteracy rate is high among them; that is 60 percent of all illiterates are women and 80 per cent of all refugees are women. This gender discrimination is apparent universally.A gender-sensitive focus on the world politics seeks to bring such challenges into open. It points out the working of international political and economic systems that tend to produce an underprivileged position for women. Jacqui True pointed out that economic development policies of structural adjustment adopted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank and changes in the international division oflabourcontribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'. Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabourare examples of how development in international economy engages in exploitation of women. Different forms of gender inequalities and discrimination may be found in advanced industrial societies even after many decades of high rates of participation of women in workfares."Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabour", are examples of exploitation of women in:
  • A.International Economy
  • B.Economies of Industrialized Nations
  • C.Economies of Developing Nations
  • D.Domestic Economy
Correct Answer: International Economy

The passage mentions that low-paid strenuous work in export processing zones, sex tourism, and migrant domestic labor are examples of how development in the international economy engages in the exploitation of women. Therefore, these examples pertain to the international economy.

Question 50
Read the passage and answer the questions that follow:Feminism is a meta-ideology that has been receiving attention in many areas of social sciences in recent decades. The starting point for introducing gender to International Relations is with respect to debate about basic inequalities between males and females and the consequences of such inequalities on World Politics. The noted works on global gender issues argue that compared with men, women constitute the disadvantaged group. They own about 1 per cent of the world's property and less than 5 per cent head higher organizations and positions while they account for 60 per cent of all working hours but receive only 10 per cent of all income. Their condition issodeplorable as the illiteracy rate is high among them; that is 60 percent of all illiterates are women and 80 per cent of all refugees are women. This gender discrimination is apparent universally.A gender-sensitive focus on the world politics seeks to bring such challenges into open. It points out the working of international political and economic systems that tend to produce an underprivileged position for women. Jacqui True pointed out that economic development policies of structural adjustment adopted by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank and changes in the international division oflabourcontribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'. Low paid strenuous work in export processing zone, sex tourism and migrant domesticlabourare examples of how development in international economy engages in exploitation of women. Different forms of gender inequalities and discrimination may be found in advanced industrial societies even after many decades of high rates of participation of women in workfares.Given below are two statements:Statement (I):The working of International political and economic systems tend to produce an underprivileged position for women.Statement (II):Economic development policies adopted by the International Monitory Fund and the World Bank contribute to an increased 'feminization of poverty'.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Both statements are supported by the information provided in the passage. Statement (I) highlights how international political and economic systems tend to create an underprivileged position for women, while Statement (II) specifically mentions the contribution of economic development policies by institutions like the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank to the 'feminization of poverty'.

Quiz Attempts 771-780 of 849
